This game has loads of potential, what this game is, is a rpg,crew and ship management, space exploration game. You get quests to do with factions and you build rep and lose rep with others. There is a lot on the surface to keep you busy like adding skills to your crew which can be over 30 members as well as a few officers which get extra skills you can promote from within your ranks. The combat and Ship battles i found to be too easy. Once you have upgrade your weapons you will never die this is EAG i am sure they will balance the final product. 

I like the quests and the main quest line. problem is they offer quest that you can't do once you have purchased new ship you have no cabin or prison so you can't do any of the quests that need those, no way of adding those compartments to your ships at this point either.  

 I was hoping to find something with a bit more depth especialy with crew interactions and the way you interact with other ships. You can't hail them to ask what they are up to talk things out. Just blow them up or fly past/retreat. The game reminds me of a shallow lake. It's fun until you have explored all the lake when it's time to jump out the boat to explore the bottom it's only waist deep. I'd like to see more animation during rpg battles to bring up the excitment.  Sound and sound track are great. More Crew managment and rift between members to add to the dept.

This is the best space/crew manament game i have found. i believe it has a ton of promise. 8/10 so far they are working hard at the game and for and EA game i put in some time because the game is on the right path
8/10

39428852.review:
Very glad I decided to pick this one up.  Even in Early Access this game feels polished and offers a ton of content.  The developers are very responsive to both forum posts and make frequent updates to the game.

Gameplay itself is rogue-like (meaning no multiple saves and on some difficulties permadeath) but with a story line with many different branches but you can also ignore the story and go about your own path (trading, exploring, killing ships and ransoming captured crew).  The gameplay is simple to pick up but has a lot of depth, I just killed my 5th captain and every new game I play I'm getting a little better and learning more about the strategic elements.

If you're a fan of space rogue-likes I definitely recommend picking this up.  Even in Early Access this game has a lot to offer and is more than worth the price.

39399422.review:
CECI EST UN PETIT BIJOU !

En très, très, très court : c'est Pirates! mais dans l'espace.

C'est un successeur spirituel de : Frontier : Elite II/Elite : Dangerous, Privateer/Wing Commander, Freelancer ou pas dans l'espace, Pirates!, Mount and Blade : Warband.

Sauf que, ah oui ! Les combats sont au tour par tour, relax, à la souris, par Action Points et Talents, un système proche de Smugglers sauf qu'ici, c'est pas répétif, sans intérêt et trop long. Il y a plein de Talents, de tactique et de façon de mener le combat entre vaisseaux.
Il y a aussi des combats terrestres, par exemple, quand on aborde le vaisseau ennemi, là aussi, c'est du tour par tour, dans le genre de Darkest Dungeon.

Mais il n'y a pas que du combat, loin de là !
On essaye d'ailleurs souvent de l'éviter ou de s'échapper parce que les réparations, ça coûte cher, l'équipage ça se blesse, ça meurt. Il faut bien choisir ses combats.

Alors c'est un jeu d'aventure/jeu de rôle avec de la stratégie. Free roaming/Sandbox.
La variété de Jobs, vaisseaux, équipage, talents, traits de caractère permet plein de styles de jeu même moins violents.

Avec la génération de cartes, la rejouabilité est très élévée.
Le jeu réussit à créer un environnement vivant.
J'ai commencé plusieurs saves et j'ai vraiment le sentiment que c'est une aventure différente. Même un membre d'équipage de longue date n'est pas le même qu'un autre. Il y a un soin apporté à créer, comme ça, un environnement avec du caractère.

Je recommande, pour la première partie, de commencer par la difficulté la plus facile pour apprendre un peu les ficelles.
C'est très simple à prendre en main et on s'amuse tout de suite mais, comme dans les bons jeux, il va falloir du temps avant de bien maîtriser.

Il y a un autosave, on ne revient pas en arrière pour faire autrement. C'est bien, chaque décision est importante.
Mais ce n'est pas un roguelike pur et dur. On peut faire des erreurs et s'en remettre. Le jeu ne cherche pas à être frustrant à tout prix. 
Les membres d'équipage peuvent mourrir et aussi les officiers et le Capitaine aux difficultés plus élevés. Là aussi, c'est jouable et pas trop hardcore, attention à ne pas prendre trop de risque avec le Capitaine, sa mort est la fin de la partie.

Pour moi, ça se joue comme un jeu d'aventure.

On crée un Capitaine ou on prend un des modèles. On parcours le monde à la poursuite de son destin, l'avenir est incertain, il faut survivre. On va pouvoir commercer, combattre, voler, rencontrer des contacts, remplir des missions pour leur compte, gagner leurs faveurs, équiper nos combattants, améliorer le vaisseau, peut-être en acheter un autre, explorer des mondes sauvages pour en piller les ressources, espionner les factions pour revendre du renseignement, patrouiller les mondes contre les pirates et les espions, bloquer les mondes pour voler les marchands ou les contre-bandiers, vendre des biens illégaux au marché noir, escorter des personnages importants, être l'envoyé d'un contact pour négocier en son nom, prendre parti dans un conflit, etc, etc, pour manipuler le monde pour notre bénéfice.

On peut faire un peu de tout au début mais, à terme, il faut mieux orienter son vaisseau et son équipage pour être efficace sur quelques activités.

Il y a des missions Story mode mais totalement optionnelles, le jeu est vraiment sandbox.
Le jeu ouvre sur la première, comme un forme d'introduction. La première mission, genre "taxi", est courte, rapide et paye bien.
Après sans spoiler, on peut faire ou pas mais ça va devenir, bon pas tout de suite, mais relativement vite relativement chaud, c'est plus pour des joueurs déjà avancés. A chacun de voir, il faut juste savoir que ça n'apporte pas d'avantage particulier pour démarrer et qu'il y a plein de choses à faire à côté.
On peut faire rien, tout ou partie du story mode, les histoires avancent et se terminent indépendamment de ce que fait le joueur.

Le côté jeu de rôle.

C'est un parfait sandbox pour roleplay les Jobs. En choisissant bien les Skills, les Talents, l'équipage, le set-up du vaisseau, avec les bons contacts, le capitaine peut devenir un très efficace chasseur de têtes qui accepte des contrats pour traquer et exécuter les criminels. Ou bien un pirate ou un espion ou un explorateur. Toutes les carrières sont vraiment viables. 
Le Capitaine et l'équipage gagnent de l'XP, montent en niveau, améliorent leurs Skills et, de temps en temps, apprennent un Talent qu'il est important de bien choisir. Au début, il faut pas mal de Talent Skill saves. Plus tard, il y a des Talents qui vraiment facilitent la vie.
Parce que, hé hé, il se passe des choses en arrière-fond même pour un simple voyage d'un système à un autre. Il y a des jets de dés permanents qui sont check contre les compétences de l'équipage ou du capitaine. Il peut y avoir un incident, un malade, une bagarre, etc qui endommage un composant du vaisseau ou la santé, le moral de l'équipage. Il y a parfois des (mauvaises) surprises. C'est surtout au début, ça se calme quand tout le monde s'aguerrit et avec les Skill saves. Il y a un log qui permet de voir dans quel domaine les jets de dés ne passent pas pour y remédier.
C'est intéressant d'explorer la panoplie des Talents qui est très large pour obtenir le build que l'on veut.

Et heu... le contexte politique.

Il y a 9 factions qui contrôlent leurs systèmes et quadrants. Il y a aussi des mondes indépendants. Et on découvrira d'autres factions mais chut ! Et peut-être d'autres trucs aussi...

Les moeurs interdisent aux factions de se mener une guerre ouverte et les conflits sont résolus en suivant des règles que l'on appelle la Shalun Law. En bref, la guerre est codifiée et limitée pour éviter l'auto-destruction de la race humaine comme cela a failli arriver par le passé. Pas de Death Star ou d'invasion planétaire mais essentiellement des combats de vaisseaux et des assassinats ciblés.

Le Capitaine gagne et perd de la réputation auprès de chaque faction en fonction de ses actions.

Gérer la réputation est sûrement l'aspect le plus difficile au début car on en perd facilement plus qu'on en gagne si on est un peu bourrin, et même sans l'être.
Alors, on apprend vite que détruire un vaisseau et son équipage est un acte très grave même si c'est de l'auto-défense. Il faut mieux neutraliser le vaisseau en détruisant ses composants vitaux et en l'abordant. Tuer le capitaine adverse, si on a la chance de le rencontrer est une victoire instantanée.

Une bonne réputation avec une faction permet d'avoir de meilleures relations avec les contacts, d'avoir accès à de meilleurs services, meilleures recrues, d'acheter des grades, des permis.
Une mauvaise réputation fait progressivement perdre le droit de commercer, de refuel, de réparation, de soins, on devient un criminel, on nous tire à vue, on a un bounty sur la tête et si on nous attrappe, c'est l'exécution sommaire.

Et donc les très intéressants contacts.

Ce sont des personnages qui détiennent des positions influentes au sein d'une faction, un juge, un ancien espion, un prince.
Ils offrent des missions et des services qui dépendent de leur fonction et de leur influence.

Le Capitaine a une réputation personnelle auprès d'eux qui se conjugue avec celle de leur faction.

On commence avec un petit carnet d'adresse que l'on développe au cours des voyages ou en étant introduit par un contact connu.
C'est par eux que l'on peut obtenir par exemple des recrues à job rare, des permis ou, dans le cas de types plus louches, un accès au marché noir. 

Leur influence varie, elle n'est pas toujours suffisante pour obtenir ce que l'on veut d'eux. On peut les aider à en gagner en travaillant pour eux et ils peuvent en perdre pendant qu'on a le dos tourné.

Je trouve cette partie particulièrement bien réussie, c'est random d'un save à l'autre et ça donne donc beaucoup de variété même sur la même carte.

Perso, je suis complètement conquis par ce jeu. C'est une pépite pour l'instant secrète.

I am a fan of Sid Meyer's Pirates (both in 1980s and remake).   I picked-up this game to be csomething different than my other games, and to kill time with for 30 mins to an hour.   I found myself playing 70+ hours in the first two weeks, and needing an alarm clock. :)

I like that it is more complex than Pirates and more things you can do.  I like the flexibility in designing your Captain and Officers.  If you get tired of one profession and want to try another just fire an officer and hire another.   No need to have lots of alts.....unless you want to try harder difficulties and different map sizes and densities.

Right now I like playing a Spy (custom template) with a ship custom designed for long, deep space missions.  My Pirate is on a harder, denser map and has been constantly fighting to survive....and leveling fast.  I have few other creative templates in mind.

Combat can be deceptivly simple, and there have been a few times when I got to relaxed and had some rough fights.

Customer service is great!  Responsive to iinquiries and suggestions with timly.  So far, content and bug patches roll out weekly.

Custom ship design was not too intuitive at first, but after some expirimentation it is quite flexible.   New patches to UI shipdesign have helped.  

I'm looking forward to see what else comes along.

39309098.review:
There's another review on here that says everything I could say, and there's really so much content in this game that I don't even want to start. I have a habit of rambling. If I can turn a Civ V review into a six paragraph diatribe about the merits of the refined policies system, I'd surely turn any review of Star Traders: Frontiers into an epic that would require at lest five full to-the-character-limit reviews worth of space.

Instead I'll try to hit the overarching points. Just know this: This game is HUGE. It is INTRICATE. It has more to it than I could ever effectively gush about in a single review. That said, here are some of the most pressing points:

+ The world feels alive. Each system you generate comes together in an organic and realistic way, with countless characters vying for position within a handful of factions which themselves are competing for resources and influence... and any one of those characters could potentially be a contact who gives you work and helps you advance your own position in the galaxy. It all comes together so beautifully.

+ With so much meat to the game, it can be a little overwhelming to orient yourself at first. Once you do, though, everything actually feels relatively tight and sleek to play. All the information you need is at your fingertips at all times, you just have to get familiar with which buttons to click to get what. Combat feels reminiscent of games like Darkest Dungeon, which was one of the immediate appeals for me, but that's only such a very small sliver of what you can do in this game.

+ The quest system even goes the extra mile in making the world feel alive, letting you choose a variety of options that kind of feel cosmetic, yet can have an effect based on stat rolls make for your crew. Will you meet with your mission-giver in the public square, with a bunch of pomp and pageantry as you pass off the parcel to him? It'll take less time if you meet him in a shady spice den, but you'll generate reputation if you do it with all the ceremony. Or maybe you want to make him come to you; really show everyone how important you are... at the risk of offending this person who your actions just helped make more influential in the galaxy. These are the kinds of decisions you make.

+ You know what? I can't even. I'm already starting to ramble. If you really want to know about the game, watch at LEAST three hours worth of a Youtube Let's Play on it, and then you'll BEGIN to scratch the surface of the content. Words truly can't do it justice, and that's not hyperbole in this case.

The few issues I have with the game all have counterpoints that offset them:

- It's too bad the factions aren't also procedurally generated, but having them preset does allow for better storytelling and inter-faction dynamics. Fortunately, their position in the galaxy IS different with each new game; all that's pretedermined seems to be their aesthetics and mentalties.

- I'd love to see this game in full 3D, but such a project would be MASSIVELY ambitious. On the plus side, the 2D aesthetic the game uses is wonderful and at times downright gorgeous planet-side. The variety in customizable crew appearances is respectable; I'd like a bit more, but I'd ALWAYS like a bit more. Objectively there are a solid handful of options that make each crew member feel like an individual, and I'm very happy with both the variety and the aesthetic itself.

- The lack of a tutorial can make things seem rather overwhelming, but I honestly don't know how one would IMPLEMENT a tutorial for a game this open and chock full of content. Fortunately, there's a nice, immersive way to call up some help dialogue about any screen in the game via calling your officers for "advice", at which point they'll regale you with most of what you need to know about what you're currently looking at.

There's a bit of a learning curve, but I wouldn't call it "steep". I got comfortable with the game's basic operations within about an hour. But do be aware that when you're getting into this one, you're getting a TON of stuff, and you might find yourself lost and confused for choice. My advice is to come in with a plan. Know who your captain is, was, or will be, and let that guide how you play. You might find yourself deviating from that and that's fine, but having that clear concept helps in getting your feet wet.

If you're on the fence about this game, I STRONGLY recommend it. The blasted thing is underpriced if you ask me. I've paid $40 for games with a quarter of the depth this game has; fun games, too. But I'd recommend maybe looking at some Youtube footage first to make sure you're ready for the deluge of cool stuff the game is gonna throw your way.

Objective 8/10, 9/10 within the space game genre, 10/10 within its genre/subgenre/aesthetic niche. If that makes any sense. Superb game all around.

39249849.review:
This review, like the game, is a work in progress.

The basics: you're a star trader, you go about the map, you do stuff. You buy and sell things to trade, you doctorize your crew to fix illnesses, repair your ship, fuel it up. Your crew can leave, you can recruit more, they level up and you can train them in jobs and skills. There's a BIG STORY THING which is presented in visual novel-ish way and you can choose different options with different risks offset by your various skills.

The initial impression I got after playing about an hour and a half is that this is a huge world filled with people and it's very Crusader Kings IIish in that you have factions and royalty and allegiances and stats and people with traits and so on. I'm not sure how much of this is procedurally-generated and how much of it you could change by interfering. I'm also, obviously, not aware of how much the story could change if you do different things. At least at this stage though there seems to be a world of possibility out there.

My very first impressions of the presentation and interface were a bit disappointing. The full body view of a person with 2D bone mechanics and an "idle animation" that makes them look a bit like a stringed puppet coupled with the almost total lack of sound effects and something about the UI made me think of it as a mobile game. There are tooltips on things though, which is a relief. The escape key seems to be used as a universal "back" shortcut in addition to there being back buttons on the interface (although there is a small bit of confusion as some screens have an x at top right to back out and some have a "back arrow" at bottom left). It would be nice if the right mouse button could be used to do the same thing as the escape key so the game could be played with the mouse only without having to move to the back buttons.

I quickly got caught up in the abundant stats and skills though and mostly forgot about the presentation. The music is in a similar vein to FTL but obviously not as good.

I didn't manage to get into person-based firefights yet but I got to test the ship to ship combat which is very nice. Rather than being tactical and grid-based the ships are shown facing each other with a number representing the distance between them. Different weapons work at different distances. You have options to move your ship towards or (I think) away, or maybe just escape. You can use weapons and you can use various skills you have as if they are cards in a board game to mitigate damage, cast off disabling effects, increase weapon damage and things like that. It's not like FTL where you walk your crew round the ship closing doors and putting out fires if that was what you were expecting, it's more like the turn-based combat you might find in a 4X space game although from the interface I'm guessing (could be wrong) that it's only ever 1 v 1 in ship battle. Animation of weapons being used was pretty good.

All in all it seems very good and I'm looking forward to playing more when I get time. Unlike a lot of other space games of this type there really does seem to be a lot to it.

39232846.review:
Star Traders: Frontiers is the latest evolution of the Star Traders series, where you fly a spaceship around, tackling various challenging missions, in the meantime handling threats such as pirates and opposit factions. You have to carefully consider how you want to play, whether you're going to be a friendly merchant, making regular, if limited, money punting materials around and being a tasty target for pirates or perhaps a tougher sort of captain, not necessarily able to cart around as much valuable cargo but able to bring bad guys to justice. Or you could just be one of the bad guys and blow everyone out of the sky.

I was pleasantly surprised that there's a great deal of depth to the game, with various characters that you meet and work with, furthering the story line, and you get to choose which ones you want to support. You'll also build up a database of contacts on various worlds, which you'll need in order to access specialist military equipment, black markets, rare goods, and additional missions.

So, I have to say that this game is well worth shelling out for. If you like space exploration, some good story-lines, a bit of fun and challenge, you should definitely give Star Traders: Frontiers a try!

In addition, it runs great on Linux and I haven't encountered any game breaking bugs so far. Which is all the more impressive when you consider that the game is still in early access.

39222739.review:
To start I'll say I've been in the shoes of people who start playing this game and aren't having much fun. You are flying around, ships are beating you up, you are broke, everyone hates you, you aren't sure what to do to fix things, and it's all confusing. From here you have 3 choices.

You can muddle through and try and figure the game out a little at a time.
You can log out and leave a nasty negative review :(
or
You can head over to the Discussion Forum in the Community Hub section for this game. Then read all the Guides in the tab up above, head over to the Tips and Tricks area and read all of those, head to the Wiki that is linked at the top of the General Forum area and browse that. Maybe even watch a 'Let's Play' video on YouTube. You then ~learn~ about the game! *Winner*

Once I did all those things my enjoyment of the game increased exponentially! The game does have a bit of a steep learning curve but once you 'get it' the game is very fun with all the ways you can play based on the different Jobs in the game. I think it's pretty standard nowdays to do at least a little bit of research into 'cookie cutter builds' and tips and tricks for almost any game. 

Pirates can beat up merchants and smugglers from blockading and sell the loot they take on the Black Market.
Military Officers can patrol planetary systems to increase their reputation with the factions.
Bounty Hunters can hunt down wanted criminals and fight them in crew combat for big bounty pay rewards.
Merchants can get high tier trade liscenses and sell expensive restricted goods for big profit.
Spies can eavesdrop on planetary systems to acquire valuable Intel records to sell for profit and contact reputation.
Zealots can soar up the military ranks and get good profit doing quests for their faction
Smugglers purchase rare trade goods and sell them on the Black Market for big profit.
Explorers can search the untamed wilderness for valuable artifacts to sell.

Even having an idea of what you want to do, it's immensely helpful to understand how to build your starting captain and their officers, which jobs synergize with each other on officers due to benefiting from the same skills, and how to build your ship and talents to best accomplish that. That is not easy to do without some research. It takes a little bit of effort on the player part but it can be rewarding if you like theorycrafting like me.

The devs are also working tirelessly day and night (just 2 guys) to improve the game and keep the content rolling it. They are also VERY active on the forums and will respond to pretty much every post, even pretty quickly if you have a concern or idea.

I look forward to all the improvements they will make to the game in early access because I know much of that is from player feedback. It's really fun now and will only get better!

Although I've played many, many games, I have never reviewed a game before, but I want to take the time for this one to specifically note that the world in this game is especially rich and rewarding. Whether following the story or playing pure sandbox, the world in this game feels very much alive by way of economy, politics, and your own network of contacts. As a captain of a starship, you're in control of a crew and the ship itself. From there, what you do and who you become is entirely up to you. In that regard, it is a great RPG. It is also a turn-based tactical combat game when it comes to the ship-to-ship and crew-to-crew fights. Finally, there are serious strategy elements similar to Mount & Blade in terms of how you position yourself within the hierarchy of characters in the galaxy. (But, similar to games like The Witcher, your character is a Star Trader, a class unto itself, who will never go on to lead a faction or become Emperor of the galaxay.) The game is immediately accessible for anyone who wants to jump in and start exploring the galaxy, but it is also deceivingly and rewardingly complex; after all these hours, I am still figuring out the various nuances of the game. 

Lastly, the game developers deserve a special shout out. In Early Access, they're very active on the discussion boards and are very good in responding to questions and suggestions. Part of the fun of playing this game right now is watching it evolve before your eyes. 

Even if you don't want to get in on it in early access, mark this one as one to watch.

39069256.review:
Really awesome game for 2 weeks into EA. Definitely worth a buy. I will only focus on the (minor) negatives here, in hopes the devs might take a look at them:

- It is very annoying to pay wages every month, considering that is approximately every 3 minutes in this game. Why do I have to land to pay my crew? That makes no sense. Why is there no auto-pay like there is auto-refuel? It makes a little more sense, although only a little more, that even if I have tons of medical bays in my ship, that I also have to land to heal my people (or get into a ship combat so I can use skills). In general, it feels like you are forced to land much more than is natural in this game. Somehow I can have a doctor trait to cure the local population with my medical bays for rep and simultaneously be unable to cure my own people.

- The achievements are all time-limited, and some of them are quite difficult and luck-based (find 15 xeno artifacts in 5 years? good luck w/o L11 exo-scout skill, which is hard to get in that timeframe). There should be a mix of "gimme" achievements and harder ones. And I think most of them should not be time-limited, because there is no possible way currently to get all the achievements without restarting many times.

- Some of the quests are literally impossible, like do 4 jumps to a target and 4 jumps back in 32 weeks.

- I broke the main arbiter quest at some point by failing a check to bribe some guards, I think I was supposed to rescue some prisoner. Once I failed, I couldn't try again or progress in any way I could find.

- Ship encounters seem somewhat too frequent. You will likely run into 3-4 ships per quadrant. I would gladly take an "autocalc battle" option for ship and crew combat, even if it meant I took more damage, because it would save me lots of time on easy encounters.

- It can become really tedious to assign skills to all your crew. There is a checkbox on character creation for "auto-assign traits", but that apparently only works for the initial crew. A feature that auto-assigns skills for non-officer characters (possibly excluding certain designated, useful characters like merchants and spies) would be useful.

- Despite the game being called "Star Traders", trading is a fairly unprofitable activity, at least measured in terms of real time per $$$. And it took me awhile, but I finally realized that there is really no major effect of supply or demand other than "buy in a supply zone type and sell in a demand zone type". If you trade basic goods with a skeleton crew, you will still run at a (major) loss, which should not be the case. If you get high-level trading permit, you might find that at most 20% of income will come from trading.

This game has a lot of potential, and I'm excited to see it realize it. Generally the biggest problem is inflicting unnecessary tedium on the player though.

You can also totally ignore the story and just play in the sandbox if thats what you feel like doing.  This game really gives you a chance to role-play out your own space narrative.

Its still a bit unpolished as its in EA but the devs are very responsive and updates come very regularly.
There is a perma-death mechanic but its optional.  I know its not everyone's cup of tea but I always play with it on - it adds so much.

Very worth checking out if you like space RPGs with a rogue-like feel or you just want to pretend you're Han Solo for a while.
Definitely worth the money considering how much replay value you can get out of it.

39036516.review:
Initial impressions of EA build:

* Interesting system of character stats / jobs / talents combined with customizable ships; it should reward some strategizing based upon the path you want to take (e.g. direct warfare, smuggling goods, legitimate and open trade, what-not) with some ability to change tracks a bit (e.g. getting wealthy as a mercenary captain destroying enemies for credits, and then buying or reconfiguring your ship for long-distance cargo hauling and favoring commerce-related skills from then on -- note that you can own multiple ships at the same time, so you can keep your ol' warship in drydock somewhere and buy a new ship for your peaceful trading.  Or maybe fire almost all your crew, buy a tiny ship, fit it with a luxury passenger cabin and pretend that it's your captain's retirement.  :D

* The number of possible paths in terms of things to do is promisingly high (trading legitimately, trying to cultivate contacts with black market access, playing space pirate, spying and selling the resulting data, exploring wilderness; staying in the service of one faction, floating around to others, etc), although it remains to be seen how well one can interact with the story-related events if, say, you're going as a pacifist merchant.  At the moment, it appears easier to interact with if you build for combat power (e.g. Bounty Hunter start) rather than something more subtle like a Spy captain.  The main story is also not yet complete (EA!).  Interacting with the story isn't mandatory, but it would be good if there are many ways to do so.

* It would be good to have documentation aside from the wiki, but... EA.  Systems, mechanics, UI are still being worked on, so there's definitely stuff to do before working on an official manual or tutorial or what-not.

* You can't be primarily a landlubber, though; nor are you a fleet commander.  You're the captain of one ship at a time, who may own other ships (but they'll be staying in drydock when you're not using them).  There's no option for being the ruler of a planet or anything like that.

* Combat is one-on-one for space combat, with certain ship and crew builds possibly favoring specific ranges; and with choice of crew/officers mattering a lot for four-on-four crew battles.  It's all strictly turn-based with some hidden information (e.g. you don't know what talents -- abilities -- or exact equipment your opponents have, although you find out when they're actually used).  It's not exactly "Silent Storm"-complex, but it's not pretending to be.

* There is a risk of RNG playing a bit of an outsize role with hit locations and critical hits at least in ship combat -- e.g. loss of your one engine -> loss of fight.  Playing on lower difficulties will mitigate said risks if those bother you; e.g. on the lowest difficulty, you and your officers are basically immortal (can be defeated in a fight but will always survive) even in events that would lead to loss on high difficulties (like surrendering to a faction that hates you so much that they'll execute you given the chance).   You can also avoid a lot of combat by bribing your way out relatively cheaply, or by having skills that significantly increase your ability to escape a fight once it starts.

* Dev team is small but extremely responsive as far as I can tell, and updating frequently.  Promising.

38890674.review:
If you like Trese Brothers games and you've been like me and waiting for the fabled Star Traders 2 to hit starport, now's your time to get excited! It's here!

I'm not going to focus on the flaws of the game because, honestly, what can you expect when there's still active development? 

Don't let its Early Access status scare you away though, the Trese Brothers are hyper vigiliant in updating content for fixes and bugs and incorporating most requests. They are active and listen to their fans and you're guaranteed nothing but improvements and enhancements. As it stands, for being Early Access this game already has a TON to offer and I'm impressed with the depth of gameplay already. You can easily get lost in the universe as is and enjoy a full gaming experience. The game runs smoothly and I've yet to encounter a glitch. There's a bit of a learning curve if you're new to the Star Traders franchise, but there is a lot in the way of resources here and elsewhere on the webs in with an active player base and the Trese Brothers both being quick to answer questions. 

If you're new to the Star Traders franchise I'll try my best to give you an idea of the game. It's a rogue-like sandbox rpg where you are your own star captain in charge of a ship trying to make their way in the galaxy, you can do that however you like, my favorite is to go for spying and or bounty hunting with a dash of exploration. You may just find it better to become a merchant instead. There's really no correct way to play the game except to strive to survive and then strive. 

Now, as I said, this is a rogue like game, what that means is that you must be very careful because there is no save point. Your game gets saved when you exit, but if you screw your ship up and have 0 creds and are stranded in the middle of space with a ship about to blow up, you can't simply restore a save point, it's game over. I bring this up because I notice a lot of individuals requesting a save system or complaining that none exists, that's as intended because the game was not meant to play like a game where your actions have limited consequences, and tbh, that detracts from the alure of the game and reduces the imersiveness of the game so, if you are absolutely tied to the hip to save points, maybe this game isn't for you, but maybe you give it a go and realize you enjoy this type of play to :-)

I may update my review as time goes on, but right now all I can do is rave incoherently. 

TL;DR 

Even if this game is in development, it's very well in depth and provides immersive sandbox rogue-like rpg gameplay. 
It'll only gain more depth in the coming months and even after its official release
If you're a vet of the ST franchise or Trese Brothers Games, I encourage you to buy this game now because I'm sure you know it can only improve and gain features like all their other games.
If you're new to the ST franchise or Trese Brothers Games, this game is supported by highly dedicated devs looking to always improve the game and your experience and they listen.
If you're new you'll also want to sit back and ask yourself if you're okay with a game that does't have a save point.

More updates to this review when I can think of more things to say.

38850364.review:
This game is deeper than any screenshot or video can show you. 
It's deeper than the impression you get even 5 hours into it.

The only games that come close to building a dynamic, interlinked world simulating economy, strife, and intrigue is the paradox games of EU4/CK2. I'm not going on hyperbole here - the world in this game is alive. 

it is a roguelike that will last you a day, a week, a month, or many months depending on success and failure. 

it is a roguelike unlike any other game. I honestly cant make an elevator pitch to illustrate what you'd be getting into. the only thing i can say is that it makes Original Star Traders look like a simplified, Mobile hack of this game - and considering Star Traders for mobile was the deepest strategy game ive played on mobile - this is no small praise.

This game is a min/max'ers dream because you can never 'get it' and coast. Every action is not linked to one stat, but 2, or 3, or more. A simple first pass min/max attempt for 'ezwinz' doesnt exist, here. The world is alive and you cannot tame it by doing a middlign effort min-max to get OP status. If you coasted through Divinity Original Sin 1 and 2 in a breeze on highest difficulty - this might be for you. If you loved the complexity of interlink/connectivity of RimWorld but needed a visceral RPG element where you had immediate goals to stay alive - this might be for you. if you are looking for a game unlike any other strategic RPG - this might be for you

It's an open world unlike any other open world.
My biggest issue with open world games is they come in two flavors: amazing combat and theme but lacking a 'real world' at all (See Wasteland2 - amazing game). it's just a series of boss fights and baldurs gates style maps to loot. the world is completely scripted, unmoving, unbreathing, unchanging, and the factions, npcs, events are all disconnected from your actions through it. any second playthrough is lackluster. then there's another open world game type: the Skyrim/Witcher - these games give you large, expansive worlds - but are again stagnant, unmoving. They dont live. Did you spend 10 hours waging war between City B and A for two different nations in Skyrim? nothing happens to affect the that nation or the neighbors. They just feel like chapters you walk through, a world that is at most a haunted house, and by no means alive.

ST is alive. It's just not easy to see in those pictures. It's again not easy to see as you go through the galaxy and see this chaotic spam of events (news) coming at you - but later, when you are no longer getting your sea legs, and you are big enough to understand the game of houses you realize that this is a dynamic, wartorn area and you have to ride the waves of conflict and intrigue to make money and grow. and you can do this in soooooooo many ways. more on that later.

many open world games have the problem of "ok, its big, its grand. but its so non-linear that i am BORED" sandbox games suffer from this - without a direct goal, you kind of lose urgency. in ST just staying alive and succeeding pigeonholes you into succeeding at all costs, through any means you can, to progress or die. Unlike too-open sandboxes, you always have immediate and long term goals. and in achieving those goals the world around you helps you, and hinders you, as it goes about its chaotic game of factions. there are missions (quest like) but that is not what you 'do'. The missions you take from NPCs are but a quarter, or less, of the missions you do for YOURSELF. You know you have to jump 4 sectors - in these 4 jumps you will plan out one way Trades where you pick up from one supply Market, dump to a demand Market, so that you are running cargo for profit just traveling the sector, you will be listening to rumors to take a detour in case there is a conflict or event that triggers rare success in specific mission types, you will hunt down VIP targets like smugglers, you will look for upgrades, and note prices.... in other words, this is a game wher eyou are giving yourself quests dynamically as you do a main quest, or pursue a main goal. This is the next innovation in gaming instead of 'go to npc, get quest, complete quest, collect reward' snooooore. ST gives you a world that is alive and you are a true freelancer - you will do everything, from explore, smuggle, bounty hunt, spy, back parties, and betray parties - all on the same character even. and only 15% of the time will it be because an NPC said to do it. the rest is pure opportunism and greed!


let me put it this way:

ive had steam for almost 14 years now.
i own near a thousand games across two accounts.
I've made but 2 reviews.
This is the second.
And before you ask: no, the first review wasnt better than this game.

MP: Starsiege:Tribes, CS (beta5 -> 1.1), SOF2, Q3, Tribes:Ascend, Call of Duty 1, Rocket League

[DISCLAIMER: I did play the Alpha, before the game was released on Steam (Despite being... Late in that game. Also in this review)]

This game isn't for everyone. Anyone can plainly see that. That being said...

It's a singleplayer, roguelike, sci-fi RPG.

Roguelike, you WILL die, and will die often. You learn from previous mistakes, and make better ones. Try, fail, fail better. Contrary to popular belief as what I've seen, there is Permadeath ONLY on Hard+

Now, RNG, yes. There is a lot. RNG encounters, RNG for Patrolling, Blockading, Spying... Space is dangerous.

The game is filled with lore, and if you take time to view the Forums, you can read about, and ask about some lore, and yes, the Devs themselves are willing to talk. They have a discord where they are very active as well. There is also a Lore PDF being made, currently, however it's not ready yet. [I will most likely edit this when it's done]

Basically, if you DON'T like: Roguelikes, Difficulty, Space, Singleplayer Only, and RNG, chances are you won't necessarily like the game.

This game is a roguelike space saga that has great potential even if is still in early access (so expect some bugs/balance changes).
What I like the most is the lore around the factions (chose your own fate as a StarTrader in a galaxy with complex politics and almost constant war/trade bans/spying) and the immersion it provides.
Story wise the game gives the player the opportunity (if he chooses) to affect major events with sometimes high risk high rewards behind it (get some legendary officers/crew combat weapons).
The gameplay is straight forward with high replay ability considering you can choose between 9 factions (each with their own strengths and weaknesses aka traits), 8 major classes (aka Jobs in game e.g. Military Officer, Spy, Pirate, Bounty Hunter, Merchant, Smuggler, Explorer) and some dozen starting ships (which affect what you are good at e.g. patrolling/blockading/spying/ship to ship combat/crew combat etc) and of course your own fully customizable Captain.
Crew management is really fun with the option of promoting officers, recruiting new crew and as the captain your decision making(major emphasis on this)  will shape them as the game progresses. Each crew will gain new traits and abilities as you start to know them better and rely on them in every aspect of handling your ship.
This journey is awesome!

38827536.review:
This game is a fantastic, budding giant, in the same vein as Templar Battleforce.  You'll definitely need a love for Sci-fi and classic turn-based RPGs, but its multi-layer approach, open world, and card-based randomizer strike a fantastic balance!  You are a ship and crew... not just a single hero, and that functionality either works as a unit, or comes apart at the seams when you forget to pay your crew on time...  >_>

EA Rating:  A-
Blind Rating:  C+    (this is completely ignoring that it's been out for only a month!)

Definitely worth the $15 even if it was released just like this... but I'm confident it's going to age into something magnificent.

Pros:
+ EXTREMELY responsive Dev team
+ Rapidly developing Early Access
+ Solid, enjoyable sandbox construction
+ Multi-layered gameplay
+ Stats are based on your collective crew... not just your hero!
+ Factional system keeps you busy
+ Has died more from my own Poor Life Choices (TM) than any cheesy game mechanics or scripted nonsense

Needs Improvement:
~ Grinding / Monotany needs improvement.  It's not at all terrible!  ^_^  But it'll need some polish before getting to 1.0
~ Graphical distinctions for weapons, armor, etc.  Currently there is a lot of rubber-stamp ships staffed with rubber-stamped characters.
~ UI is in rapid development, but will need more Ease of Use work before it's truly ready
~ While the graphics are passable, they'll need to go just a bit further than they already are in one direction or another.  Either towards the flat Tactical RPG style, or the cell-shade Story RPG style.  Currently dabbles in both (and looks good!) but still needs to level up a bit.
~ Extreme expansion of weapons, armor, and equipment (reluctant to mention this, as it's already planned!)

Negatives:
- Old School design, lacking in any real deep instructions.  (I take this as a positive... but many may not!)
- EA bugs (mostly script / visual / balance, not crashes or glitches)
- Some storylines abruptly end (again, see EA)

Suggestions:
?  Would definitely suggest distinct factional traits, strengths, etc.
?  Desperately needs a proceedurally generated, random loot and equipment system.  A little Diablo or Torchlight would go a LONG ways in a game like this.
?  Ships need to be more empty than they are currently, and rely more on tonnage and less on 'slots'.  This allows more lateral customization and variations of a single design (... but also min-maxing, for better or worse)
?  Consider mod support.  There are players and modders out there that will HAPPILY expand content violently for you, if you make those mods visible and accessible on Steam. (ie. Rimworld)

The dev's are genuinely active in reviewing information provided by the players. They are attentive, and are aggressively updating the game. Feedback is driving the development of the game, but it's applied to the vision, that they clearly have for this engrossing sci-fi setting. (Though I would like to see Aliens in this type of setting, and a diverse array of technology, that most likely is another game some day.)

But, now to the meat of the game. As a pre-review, and it being an Early Access game that is changing daily.

The hard sell is simply, a Thumbs Up. I would recommend it. 

With the caveat, that there will be updates that make the game better, but who knows how it will affect your game style.

There is a lot in this gem to unpack. But that having been said, it's a play the game, find what you like and don't like, and feel free to comment on it. There currently are a few quirks that would of been really useful to know going into the game.

1. When you are on a planet and want to get to the main menu, you will leave the orbit of the planet to go back to the solar system map, and if you haven't finished your business on the planet, well you'll have to land again and consume fuel to do so. (This is something that needs to be addressed soon, there needs to be a way to save what you are doing on a planet and be able to go back to the main menu and log out of the game.)

2. Your crew CAN and WILL be damaged while flying through space, as the game generates events that the crew will have to roll against. So make sure to keep track of how damaged they are and visit the Medical facilities on planet to get them healed up.

3. Money will be tight in the beginning including if you are an actual Trader. So make sure to try to stay on top of your money intake and outlays.

4. You are on your own in the beginning without any explanation to what is a normal guideline for Key Stats, and Skills. But give it a shot, and run with it.

This is a really great game as-is and with a reactive development team it's easy to see how bright of a future ST:F has. 

Real quick I'll list out what I like: 
[list]
 [*] Strategic Flexibility (about 10 or so different ways to make money and advance your standing in the world) 
 [*] Conflicting Factions (You can help or hurt each faction and you have reputation with each)
 [*] Conflicting Contacts (Each contact you have has relationships with other contacts and they can give you missions to help their cause or hurt their opponent's) 
 [*] Customization! (Everything is pregen but you can create a new Galaxy to romp around in and customize your crew look as well as skills composition, leveling, and equipment) 
 [*] Autosaving (Make good decisions because there's no saving, you scum!)

38463194.review:
I really like this game.   But I have stopped playing it for now.

This game is a rogue-like space adventure.  As soon as you start you have to make decisions about character creation.   You can boost your stats up OR you can go with lower stats and a mid-game ship plus other goodies at start.

Basic gameplay is doing missions for people.   This increases rep and then opens doors to better rewards and more missions.   Your basic RPG style.   You can choose just to trade, smuggle, or be a pirate if you like too.   But you will have the chance to do all these things when completing the missions.   So why not make a little extra?

You upgrade your character as you level up by earning XP.   You use money to upgrade your ship and pay your crew.   And that's where this game really shines to me.   Crew Management.

Crew management means that along with your Captain Character, your crew will level up as well.   Your captain and your officers can have three jobs.  All other crew have can only have one job.   Jobs open access to special use skills for combat, mini games (smuggling, exploring, spying, etc. are all minigames), and back ups in the event of failed saving throws.  Jobs also provide stats that help when making those saving throws and with weapon accuracy during combat.  Upgrading your ship gives you access to more crew and officers.

It's a great game but the reason I am going to set it aside for awhile is that it's not complete.   However, the devs have a plan and are very rapidly implementing features from their roadmap.   I just don't want to burn myself out before more of these features are put into the game.  Fortunely, I don't think I will have to wait very long.

I've put about 8 hours into this very broad and also very deep game, never really playing much beyond the intro section, just trying to digest its systems. And for about a week I've followed the updates and the forums and I have this to say.

This is probably the best example of a team using agile development strategies, and responding to their clients/customers complaints in insanely short amounts of time. 

The frequent updates and expansions of content, promises of systems tweaks, and above all, active, supportive and present developers, clearly communicating things to the players, is enough that I'd make a recommendation just based on that.

But, and there's a big but here. The fact that the game is fun to play, feeling like a kind of simulated game of the pen and paper game, Rogue Trader. With complex, but accessible systems. To a, "Buy this game, the price point is right for an Early Access game, and has good core gameplay, and has active developers,"

Overall, my only complaints are thus,

The UI needs a usability pass. 

-Things in the character creation that make no sense. If attributes start at an amount and you cannot lower them below that amount, why does the bar start mid way through?

-Why not use those bars on the skills screen instead to unify the aesthetic.

-The Contacts screen could be clearer on what exactly each contact does, maybe a seperate panel on the right side of the screen giving you a breakdown of each thing a contact offers when you click on them.

I could go on and if I continue to play this game, I just might go on, but in a seperate forum thread. But the long of it is above and the short of it.

Super fun, super accessibly complex, lots of variety in gameplay, lots of choices to make, shakey UI, with a dev team that is amazing so far. I may update this review in the future. Again if I keep playing this game. Which I might, because it scratches an itch very few games manage to scratch.

38362282.review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
The game isn't polished in any area, but it has potential.  Trese Brothers has a long history of updating their games well after release, so I fully expect they will continue to work on it until that potential has been realized.

If you rage at rogue-like games where a couple bad decisions or random events could cause a death-spiral, then this is probably also not the game for you.  (Save-scumming is possible with a little technical know-how, but there's no manual saving as I write this.)

There are legitimate complaints that there can be an annoying mixture of hidden complexity, purely random outcomes, and a lack of options/control.  (Complaints that the developer actively listens to and  engages in fruitful discussions.)

But if you're looking for a single-player, moderately open-world, turn-based space adventure game, you're in luck.  If you'd like to help influence the development of such a game, now would be the time to get it and join in.

[h1]Personal History/Take[/h1]
The original Star Traders on Android was my first and deepest experience with Trese Brothers.  I've bought every game of theirs since, either on Google Play or Steam.  I did it because I believe they needed rewarded for the sheer commitment they show to their games.  That original Star Traders game?  It's [b]still[/b] getting updates, even years later as they work on the sequel.

Unfortunately, Trese Brothers games were in a sort of awkward place for me--too involved to be a "play it for 10 minutes every other week" mobile game, but not involving enough to compete with "real games" on the PC.

ST:F changes that for me.  Even in this early version, I see the game as a worthy addition to my Steam list and it's rapidly climbing my game list in terms of time spent playing.

[h1]A Mostly Open-World Space Adventure[/h1]
Just create a character and go.  You start out with a ship (including crew) and get introduced to the game's storyline.  Run with that story or completely ignore it and go do whatever you want to do.  You can be a simple trader, a privateer, a hired gun, a military officer, an explorer, a spy, or any mixture of the above.

Just be prepared:  Probably at least 1/3 of the galaxy will end up hating you.  Most missions are going to be against a faction (who aren't going to appreciate it).  Selling goods could cause someone to hate you.    Hell, just passing by a ship can cause you to lose a little bit of reputation.

You are not alone in flying through space.  Your ship has a crew and officers.  Your crew level up as you do things and can gain "talents" which are special abilities such as saves for certain bad conditions, special attacks, and the like.  Each crewmember has their own traits and morale.  Too many bad things happening at once or just continued neglect (such as not paying them) may cause a crewmember leave--or, if enough of the crew becomes demoralized, you could literally have a mutiny on your hands.

The overworld portion is definitely the highlight for now:  Flying through space (with the game tossing dice in the background to see if you pass skill checks).  Landing on planets.  Managing your ship/crew.  Maybe a little trading.  Talking to contacts to get services and missions.

Contacts are a key addition over the original mobile game.  They are your interface with a given faction.  If you don't have a contact with an associated faction, you can't get missions, get ranks/permits, or even pay to absolve your transgressions.  Getting in good with a contact generally gets you better/more of what they offer.

There are a few different mission types, but most are the usual fetch/carry quest or kill/capture something quest.  There are some special-purpose quests like "spy on someone" or "explore this unpopulated area/planet".  Again, usually a mission will gain you reputation with the issuing faction (as well as the contact), but at the cost of reputation of another.

Missions lead to what is probably the weaker elements of the game at this early stage.

Exploring, patrolling, and spying all use "cards".  You're shown five result cards.  You press a button and four cards slowly disappear.  The remaining card is your result.  The result may trigger a battle or a save roll.  Some crew talents let you modify the cards before pressing the button, but that's it really.  The process has all the strategy of pulling the arm of a slot machine.

Ship battles offer a little more in the area of strategy.  Each turn you can decide if you want to advance/retreat, then what weapons to use, and finally if you want to activate any crew talents.  Both sides execute their selected actions.  Rinse and repeat until one ship escapes or is destroyed/disabled.  The only variation is the ability to send a boarding crew, which takes us to crew combat…

If you've played Darkest Dungeon, you know the basics of crew combat--4v4 turn-based battles where individuals have special abilities, usually tied to party position.  It's the most strategic of the "doing stuff" part of the game.  It could use some more depth, but it is the most interactive component in the game at the moment.

So, the game isn't the best thing ever made, but it also was just released in Early Access.  It's also being actively worked on by a pair of guys who are personally invested in every one of their games and listen to their customers.  I paid double the current asking price in the Kickstarter and I feel I've already gotten my money's worth.

38325975.review:
This is an extremely promising game, and even in its early access state it can suck you in. The game is somewhere between a space sim and a sandbox RPG/roguelike, and has a great deal of depth if you are willing to scratch beneath the surface. 

For example; your contacts (who provide missions, equipment, etc) all have both a faction allegiance and an influence score within their faction. This means that by aiding them you can increase their influence, allowing you to become a sort of kingmaker. This level of detail is given to many of the game's features, with the result being a universe that feels much more alive than that of similar games.

Some people may be put off by the Early Access tag (understandably), but the developers are extremely active, with consistent weekly or even bi-weekly updates. They are also receptive to feedback through the discussion page, and it is very likely that the finished product will meet all the expectations of the playerbase.

In short: good game already, potential to be great, excellent developers.

38254060.review:
Star Traders: Frontiers is a sci-fi rogue like RPG game where you take the role of a captain of a star ship. You make your character (visually as well as picking skills, stats, and a job), and then set out on adventure. What happens after that is basically entirely up to you. Want to be a part of a story that takes place no matter if you decide to help out or not? Want to be a pirate or part of the system defense? Want to be a merchant, or explore, or hunt criminals? 

The ship-to-ship combat system is fairly simple yet interesting for what it is. The ground combat is heavily inspired by Darkest Dungeon. 

There are a multitude of different bulds you can do and each playthrough will be different. The Tres Brother are pretty fast with coming out with updates for this Early Access game, adding content and features, fixing bugs, etc. They're also good at communicating with their Early Access players through different forums.

There's enough customization for setting up the game in a way you like to play (don't like permadeath, then pick a difficulty without that, and so on; fully customizable difficulty settings is a feature on the list to come).

I'm hoping for some more end game stuff but AFAIK the devs have said that's something that will come eventually. It's easy to see the potential already for anyone who wants to be a space captain.

38244786.review:
This is early access done right.  Updates come every couple of days, and all of them come with published notes.  The game has a lot of little flaws and annoyances in its UI but every update there are fewer.  Every update something looks better, or there's a new ship or mission, or something works better.  There's only two developers working on this game but they somehow manage to fully engage with their players and still have time to work on the relentless update schedule.  I hope they thrive.

The game has what's important for a sandbox open world: you can tell there's a lot of data moving around in the background making every region, planet and person detailed enough to feel alive in a procedurally generated universe.  There is a lot to do in the game, and there's a lot more depth than what you'll get from first impressions.

One of the best places for info outside the game, the official Trese Brothers forums, doesn't rank as high as it should in Google search results.  Look for the proboards links in your searches and you'll tend to find what you're after faster, while the official and best wiki to use is the gamepedia one.

38221361.review:
Who the heck wrote this game, the French?

OK, this game has a lot of excellent game mechanics and the story has potential but there are a number of things that simply irritate me about the lore and game balancing decisions.

The idea that you are operating in faction space that is friendly to you but that there are other faction ships that can intercept you and board you at their whim is more than a bit unrealistic. I mean seriously, a rival faction merchantman is really going to destroy its rep in a sector it's trading by intercepting you and either fighting or boarding you? Pirates and zealot's, OK, but merchants and explorers? And the game basically forces you to surrender because the cost of battle is almost always higher than any reward, not to mention rep loss for taking out a pirate.

And that's the other thing, the rewards for missions are generally small to the point of making missions cost more than you make if you haven't leveled a crew up sufficiently to avoid, again, unrealistic damage.

The game forces you to exploit a limited number of game mechanics to survive and doesn't provide much guidance on what they are or how to utilize them.

That said, it was fun figuring some of this game out and though it isn't really for me I think a lot of people will enjoy it and I therefore give a conditional recommendation.

38220084.review:
This is the game I have waited for since I played 'Frontier: Elite II' back in the nineties.

You are a star trader captain, travelling between planets and quadrants, seeking for glory, wealth, battles, alien artifacts... well, mostly you will be seeking to survive to see the next day.

You can play story missions if you like, but you can also just play sandbox style. You can even mix both playstyles.

There are different ways to reach whatever your goal might be, your captain can be a combination of a whole lot of classes like merchant, pirate, explorer, bounty hunter, diplomat, smuggler, swordsman, spy, soldier, doctor, navigator, pilot, etc.

Crew management is an important part of the game. You have to choose wisely which officers will complement your captains skill the best way and what kind of crew members will be needed to keep your ship running. Keeping an eye on crew's health and morale is absolutely vital.

The game also features challenging ship-to-ship combat and crew combat. You can purchase new ships, refit an old freighter to some heavily armed battle cruiser or keep slipping through enemy patrols with that shabby small smuggler vessel you started on.

Lots of political factions are interacting with each other, you can work for one or more of these, if you like. Choose your friends wisely, and your enemies as well. The void is not unforgiving, but it's really close to that.

The game is still in Early Access. You might encounter bugs, incomplete story arcs and things that need balancing. The good news is, that the developers (Trese Brothers) keep firing out one update after the other, fixing bugs, implementing new stuff and balancing the game to improve the players'  experience. They actually DO listen to their players' feedback, responding to every single question/bug report/feedback given to them after very short time. Never seen such devotion and passion in support.

Though not finished yet I already love this game.

If you enjoyed classics like 'Elite', 'Pirates!' or 'High Seas Trader', you will love this one.
If you watched and loved 'Firefly' and you are desperate because there might never be more than 14 great episodes and one movie... here's the closest gaming experience to flying the serenity you will find.
If you were bored by jedi religion and force using in Star Wars but always wanted to live Han Solo's rogue trader life... well, what are you waiting for?

38209598.review:
[u][b]Un jeu exceptionnel.[/b][/u]

Vous incarnez le Capitaine d’un vaisseau dans un univers gigantesque. Que vous soyez pirates, contrebandier, chasseur de prime ou simplement marchand, l’impression de liberté est totale.

Vous avez le choix...

[i]Le choix.[/i] C'est le maitre mot, dans ce jeu.

Et un choix réel. On a le choix de s’intéresser à la Quête principale ou non. De toute manière, il y a toujours de quoi faire. Des tonnes de missions, de personnages avec qui converser, de dangers à éviter. Rien que de s’occuper des dizaines de membres de son équipage (chacun leurs traits, leurs compétences et personnalité...) est déjà passionnant.

Tout, ou presque, a été pensé dans ce jeu. L’Univers est peuplé, les planètes diversifiées et les factions y régnant nombreuses. Il est réellement intéressant de recueillir les rumeurs et les avis de tous afin de se faire une idée sur notre position politique, car chaque rencontre se règlera en fonction de cela.

[i][b]Les adeptes du tour par tour seront aux anges.[/b][/i]

L’Univers est vaste et cohérent. Le système de carte aléatoire vous garantit un nouveau monde à chaque partie. On peut donc rejouer à l’infini, sans se lasser avant longtemps.

Les combats spatiaux sont statiques. Ici, pas de vue en 3D à la con et de temps réel ingérable. Tout se fait au tour par tour et implique directement les compétences de vos personnages. Tout comme les combats [i]« au sol »[/i] (abordages, missions de votre équipage...) qui ressemblent beaucoup à ceux de [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] (ce qui est une VALEUR SURE, non ?). J’adore. J’en fais une véritable addiction, allant même parfois (ce qui n’est évidemment pas à faire, croyez-moi... rires) jusqu’à les provoquer.

Dans ce jeu, donc, vous êtes [i]réellement[/i] le capitaine de votre vaisseau dans un univers aussi vaste que plausible où le danger est partout. Que ce soit un pirate qui vous aborde à votre sortie d’une planète où vous venez d’acheter une cargaison d’épices rares, ou la milice vigilante d’une faction avec laquelle vous n’avez que peu d’affinités, vous devez toujours prendre garde où vous mettez les pieds et à la façon dont vous le faites.

Et je ne parle même pas du système de [i]contacts[/i]... Vous en choisissez à la création de votre personnage et en gagnez (et perdez, je suppose) d’autres durant la partie. Politiciens, anciens chasseurs de prime, Princes, Fixers et j’en passe. Vous devez jouer avec vos relations, leur rendre visite et affiner celles-ci. Et nous ne parlons pas ici de vains points de règles. Cela a un impact réel sur votre jeu.

Vraiment, on peut tout faire. En jouant mon personnage, j’ai eu cette impression folle d’être un Han Solo me faisant des ennemis de partout. Je n’ai fait que la petite portion de départ, en suivant plus ou moins la quête principale (qui a l’air passionnante). J’ai été rencontré mes différents contacts, participé à leurs rivalités avec d’autres factions et personnages. Incroyable comme le nombre de conflits s’est multiplié. Tant de richesses dans le background ! Tant de choses à faire... je n’avais presque plus de temps pour la quête principale que j’ai rapidement mis de côté... trop pris par mes « ennuis personnels »... Rires. Et pourtant, y a du boulot avec la quête « que je suppose » principale.

Bref, je n’ai pas la prétention d’être un expert en jeux vidéos. Mais je prends un tel pied en jouant à celui-ci que je ne peux que vous le conseiller. Faut encourager ces Trese Brothers, car ils font des jeux où l’esthétique est au second plan laissant la place à une richesse et une profondeur sans égale. Bravo.

Pour vous faire une idée, je vous donne ce lien d'un de mes abonnements Youtube (je pense que l'interessé ne s'en ofusquera pas) : [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a03s3fj76ao&t=265s]Un petit tuto en français[/url]. J'ai trouvé ces vidéos très sympas et assez complètes pour pouvoir commencer à jouer dans les meilleures conditions.

Bon. Assez de bla-blas, allez jouer à ce jeu, maintenant.

Finally a game again that gives you really the impression of commanding a spaceship and its crew. 

First you might think it consists of a bunch of minigames and all the skill tests while travelling are confusing, but after a while you realize it all makes sense. The game is far, far less random than you might think at first. In fact it's really stat driven. The game is entirely turnbased and open world.

You can manage your officers and crew - similar to old school rpgs - use their talents and fight with them. You can trade, smuggle, do missions for your contacts, spy, look out for friendly or hostile ships, negotiate and explore the wilderness of planets.

What I like especially and I would consider some sort of groundbreaking are the different contacts and different factions you  keep business with. It's similar to the pnp Shadowrun rpg or Crusader Kings. That's how you should handle contats, mission givers and different factions! (I'm looking at you Elite Dangerous...). Another favourite of mine is smuggling which is actually fun here with a proper black market and all.

The game might interest you or is recommended if you like games like Starflight, roguelike Prospector, Space Rangers 2 and Pirates! 

Even in early access the game is already a lot of fun and the developers are known for constantly improving their games with good customer support.

38067589.review:
****Update After More Gamplay*******
This game is also very deep. Even after dozens of hours of gameplay I am still learning new things and reaching new thresholds and seeing there is more. The game gets more complex as you face the concequences and rewards of your choies.
***END***
[TLDR]
This game is basicly Warhammer 40k Rogue Trader d20 RPG Rule Set in a Procedurally Generated Map with a ton of Factions arguing over who shoudl be in charge of the galaxy. 

***Overview***
The Meat of the game is doing missions, trading, and a card based mini game that shows you all the possible outcomes before you try something and allows you to use your crews abilities to give you some rerolls on the card choices. It is actually quite terrifying as you can see your objective on one card, and your crew dying on the card next to it and know that either one is a possible outcome. You use this mini game for 3 activities whcih take place in the Orbital layer of gameplay. You can try to SPY on people. Maybe hack into nearby comms systems or satlites and learn some stuff people don't want you to know. You can PATROL the area and attack smugglers and pirates to increase your faction standing or to complete a mission objective. When you BLOCKADE you are trying to find a smuggler or merchant to rob them of there cargo. All 3 of these mini games use the card based system. Other then that there is alot of talking to people and gaining information or making choices based on how you have decided to play. 


The story so far is amazing. If you decide to just skip the story missions and start flying around someone with a story mission might come find you or you might just accidently end up on a planet that has a story mission and they will contact you while you are on the planet and talk to you. If you simply choose to help no one the story goes on and at any time you can decide to intercede but your inactions have consequences too. For example if you help them deliver things but aren't willing to attack people jsut yet then they will not send anyone out to attack there enimies and eventually there enimies will come attack them. Someone might lose. They might send word to you to help with the new side of the crisis they are dealing with. Ignore the again and the story moves on. Help them and the story changes. Help them but fail a bunch of skill checks and the story changes again. It feels organic but you know its not and it made me really appreciate the work that went into a section of the game that isn't a labor of love for other simulations like this one. The story is not completely implemented yet and some of the side characthers and quests will simply tell you that if you try to access them but I am excited to what they do with these opportunities.


While flying around the game is constantly rolling skill checks for piloting, repairing accidents as they come up, special ablities are being used automaticlly and going on cooldown for 3 weeks. Its all happening, you can see its going on, and even effect it by getting more expierenced crew, incresing your ships systems, etc.... But the idea that at some point your going to fail a bad skill check and your ship is going to be damaged, one of your awesome crew might die due to suffocation during a fire, or someone might make it to the doctor and die because the doc saved somebody last week automaticlly so he has 2 weeks more on his cooldown and he only rolled a 2 on his skill check. He needed to roll a 10 or better. And all of that can be simply ignored. The game can be played without focusing on this information.


You get into this weird rythm every time you land on a planet.You buy gas, repair your ship, have everyone healed at the doctor on planet as long as the planet has enough medical supplies, you get everyone stoned on space spice (again as long as they have enough drugs to supply you), you pay there wages, recruit new crew for anyone that has left in the dead of night or died by being decapitated and then sell your goods and check the exchange prices to see what is being sold here and what people are buying. All of this makes your crew happy, makes them want to train hard at there job and gives them xp, and ensures that they will listen to you when it counts and stick around for the hard times. You really start to care about your crew. They are so valuable and you can really customize them to fit certain rolls. Some of your guys are so awesome that they are given there own room on the ship. They command respect from the others and act as leaders, keeping them inline while in combat, or on shore leave. They gain access to alot more classes and can take up to 3 classes total. Captains can be 1 out of maybe 6 or 8 options as a class in the begining, regular crew are normally 1 class out of maybe 6 - 8 different classes then the previous mentioned ones. When a charcther is an officers or captain they gain alot of extra levels and can multiclass taking any of the 12-16 total classes available. All of these classes gain skills every time you take them. Its small but it progresses quickly. And every couple of levels you gain an ability. This could be soemthing like a save when you fail a roll for something specific. Lets say you make an engineering check, your mechanic knows a skill that lets him pass a failed test once every 3 weeks. After that the mechanics ability goes on a 3 week cooldown. But if you have more then one crew member with the same save you can use more then once in a 3 week period. Or the ability could be something to buff your ship in combat or an attack you use when fighitng in combat.

This brings me to the last subject. The Combat.
There are two types.
Ship combat is a 1v1 fight with another ship. Every hit counts and lucky shots can cause, you guessed it, skill checks, and failing these could lead to something really bad happening. If the engines go out or you lose alot of your hull or crew during a fight then the fight is over. Depending on the difficulty of the game this could mean simply going back to the map with your crew badly beaten and a loss of all of your cargo and/or fuel and limping back to port with an angry crew if you are playing on easy. If you are playing on harder difficulties then everyone dies, the ship explodes, you all vent into the void. I AM HOPING IN THE NEAR FUTURE THAT WE WILL BE ABLE TO EDIT AND CUTOMIZE THE DIFFICULTY SETTINGS!!!!!

Squad Based Combat ala Darkest Dungeon is the other combat in the game. Somtiems you will land on a planet for a mission and you end up running thru the city getting chased by guards after failing a skill check during diologues. You fail another skill check and you go into combat vs 4 other guys. Anyone in your crew can be chosen for combat. Anyone who dies in combat will have to roll a death save depending on the difficulty setting with  2 possible outcomes. They are really messed up or they are dead.

***Verdict***
All of this adds up to a game that is awesome. If you like RPGs, Simulations, sid meiers pirates, space games, space rangers 2, warhammer 40k, rogue trader, board games, or just thought what I wrote in my review was like video game porn then pay 15 bucks and help shape this game before the idiots start talking about fair and balanced.
