38044011.review:
At the time of writing I have barely two hours into the game and I find myself engrossed in the game world's atmosphere already. 

You start out by creating a captain and that itself is an involved process. First, you choose a class that can offer various benefits and skill bonuses at the start. Then you choose what facet of your character is the most important and set up priorities for things like your starting ship, starting experience, personal attributes, skills, your pre-existing contacts in hte world. The higher you set the priority, the better quality/quantity of it you receive.

With your ship as the topmost priority for instance, you can claim one of the largest starting ship and have some spending cash to boot. If your contacts were the highest priorities, you get a handful of them right off the bat.

The game itself revolves around making saves against hazards and the game will roll against events and situations in the background, based on the total of your crew skills where applicable, or your personal skills and attributes in some cases. 

Ship to ship combat is simplified into an overhead view of both involved vessels exchanging fire in a turn based mode. If and when boarding occurs, you pit four of your best crew to fight against four of the enemy's, which will then result in either a positive or negative outcome. Crew combat is turn based as well and reminiscient of Darkest Dungeon in its presentation.

The economy and trade is straightforward but even there you can use your captain's or your officers' and crew's skills to negotiate a better deal. This goes for missions as well as diplomatic situations.

Oh yeah, you have a handful of officers who fulfill critical roles on your ship, level up more than simple crew members can. Each crewmember is also represented as an individual that has a class and skills, all contributing to the overal performance of your vessel!

Overall this game has RPG leanings and yet feels like a proper space game to me.

There are a few aspects that are sure to receive some polish - check the roadmap to be certain. The interface is occasionally glitchy but servicable and for a tooltip addict like myself, there aren't nearly enough! Expect a few trips to the wiki until you can memorize what each skill and attribute does for you.

Other than that, you know what you're buying into, this is an early access title, so expect the occasional bug and missing content near the end of your play time, but at the time of writing, there's more than enough to do in the game right now and for the current price of €15 this is definitely well worth it in my honest opinion.

Also, the developer is active in the forums and judging by their past releases, this game is going to be well supported after full release.

38019300.review:
I backed this game on kickstarter, and I played this game in its early Alpha stage before it was released on Steam, so I have played this game far longer than 0.6 hours.

There are a lot of ways to play this game. You can be a pirate, explorer, merchant, bounty hunter, spy, or whatever else you want to be, and each "profession" does not lock you out of the activities of other professions. So, if you want to be, say, a bounty hunter who explores wild zones on the side, you can do that.

There are two kinds of combat: crew and ship battles. They are both turn based. Crew combat pits 4 of your crew against 4 enemies, and you can have access to healing abilities and powerful attacks based on how you trained your crew. I have often heard STF crew combat is very similar to the combat in Darkest Dungeon, but I cannot confirm that as I haven't played DD. I don't want to talk too much about ship combat here because the balance may change drastically in future updates (such as when "small craft combat" gets implemented).

This game is very good, but it's not for everyone. It is very deep, so if you don't like games with a steep learning curve than this game probably isn't for you.

Made by the ultra-responsive and hyperspeed-patching developers Trese Brothers (Templar Battleforce, Cyber Knight, Star Traders 4x: Empires--all quality mobile games, just try them yourself if you need proof), this is truly a labor of love, born from a Kickstarter project some years ago, I've anticipated this game--and it quite simply delivers.

Even in its Early Access status, with their attitude of taking feedbacks from all the STF players on bug reports and various improvements, I wouldn't be surprised at all if this gem would be polished into brilliance that it rightly deserves.

PROS:

CONS:

- Minor typos
- Rare instances of crashes

38001295.review:
Aunque la reseña esté en castellano, EL JUEGO ESTÁ EN INGLES.

Tengo que reconocer que soy un fan de los hermanos Trese. Lo primeor de ellos que jugé era una adaptación del clásico de tablero Space Hulk, que más tarde se convertiría en el Templar Assault. Jugé hace tiempo al Star Trader, y al Templar Battleforce (al que le he metido menos horas de las que me gustaría). Así que cuando se anunció este nuevo Star Traders me interesé, y cuando empecé a ver todo lo que iba a tener, me gustó más.

El juego mezcla exploración, comercio, espionaje, piratería, combate espacial, combate terrestre, y lo mezcla con un estilo muy "vieja escuela" en lo que a contenido y variedad se refiere, pero con un estilo gráfico fresco y moderno. 
El universo del juego bebe de Dune, Warhammer 40k y otras muchas obras (he pillado referencias a Heinlein y a Asimov mientras jugaba). Y para mi es algo en lo que los hermanos Trese excelen, en amalgamar ideas en algo propio, como para mi pasa con Templar Battleforce.
El juego promete muchas horas de exploración, comercio, piratería, etc, y tener una trama considerablemente elaborada, que unido a todo el contenido comercial, político (con muchas facciones continuamente evolucionando y enfrentándose) parece que va a dar para mucho y que tendrá un cierto grado de rejugabilidad. 
Eso si, el juego no tiene una curva de aprendizaje suave (principalmente por la falta de tutoriales, un resumen de las reglas o similar). Entiendo que en gran medida esto se debe a que está en Acceso Anticipado y que es algo que en la versión definitiva se solucionará, sobre todo porque se que en los otros juegos de los hermanos Trese es así. 
Además, mi experiencia con ellos es que responden enseguida y solucionan los problemas. Encontré el primer día un error en linux, lo comuniqué y a los minutos me respondían que no era prioritario pero lo corregirían en cuanto pudiesen, y una semana después estaba solucionado. 
Y otra cosa a tener en cuenta (al menos para mi) es que dan soporte a Linux.

Escribo esto con solo 6 horas de juego a mis espaldas, que no es mucho, pero suficiente para poder decir que yo estoy encantado con el juego y no puedo recomendarlo más. Está claro que no es algo que vaya a gustar a todo el mundo, y recomiendo buscar vídeos en youtube para ver como se juega, pues con poco que veas enseguida te darás cuenta de si es un juego que te puede gustar o no. 
A mi me está encantado.

37969277.review:
Don't let the name fool you. Star Traders Frontiers is about a lot more than just trading. Piracy and privateering, spying and smuggling, battles in space and on strange planets, you pretty much do it all, from epic quests to shake galactic politics to mundane fedex legwork and space uber. You have the freedom to roleplay the kind of starship captain you want, and the game mechanics support a variety of playstyles and preferences, though some are more developed than others right now and others are no more than a simple minigame. 

The most ambitious part of the game is the political simulation of NPC actors. Although the territories and borders of the map are disappointingly static, the landscape of factions, cliques, and agents is dynamic and ever-changing and makes you feel like you're part of a living universe. Factions are always in conflict, sometimes in a hot or cold war, sometimes allying against another faction, and your actions as a player can influence the outcome of these conflicts. Those outcomes then affect the individual actors within the factions, making some more powerful and others less. Strong actors can then use their influence to pursue their agendas based on their procedurally-generated characteristics, possibly creating new conflicts, whereas weak actors become vulnerable to the agendas of their rivals. While the player's actions have a larger significance, the depth and complexity of all these interlocking systems makes said actions have butterfly effects that are hard to predict or understand. The result is richly emergent storytelling over a backdrop of war, conspiracy, betrayal, and assassination. 

Now the bad news. The early access build is really rough around the edges. The interface is frustratingly obtuse and a lot of important mechanics are poorly documented (if documented at all) or halfway implemented (though this is changing as the devs implement more tooltips and QOL changes.) There isn't even manual/multiple saving, which might make sense for a roguelike with quick turnaround but is completely absurd for an RPG with lengthy campaigns, and strongly penalizes the kind of experimentation that would truly demonstrate the depth of the abovementioned systems. Game needs a lotta work, for real. 

Still, the game has tremendous potential and the simulation is interesting enough that I am able to overlook these problems and keep playing in the sandbox, even if it means having to externally manage save files. The game is also being updated frequently enough that these impressions will probably be outdated very soon.

Critique below: *This may seem a bit harsh, but know this critique comes from my excitement to see the game completed and well done. I am genuinely enthusastic about the developement of the title. Devs are outstanding!*
-----
 I do look forward to seeing the card mechanics either thrown away or redone. It's too shallow for my taste. The experience of spying, blocading, exploring, and all of it's potential for fun is dulled away by just clicking one single button to roll the dice for cards. This is shallow. This is cheap and it needs attention. Beyond that the other complaint that I have is how missions are given out. If I am playing as a faction then I want the missions to matter. I don't want it to be a numbers game of where I just see the reputation number increase, and nothing of great import happens beyond the fact that my number for repuation with said faction is now higher. If I am given a mission I want an experience to happen to me that is memorable. I don't want another video game with side quests that don't matter and are only good for gaining more numbers in my xp bar or loot. I want meaningful experiences now. I'm too damn old to be entertained by just dull and lifeless side-missions in my games! Make them interesting or throw the idea away. I wouldn't mind the game being full of this great writing that you have started already. If each mission mattered, was an event that counted in the grand scheme of things, and was interesting then I would smile and carry on. The campaign story line missions are excellent so far from what I've seen in terms of telling a story. Mechanic-wise they are basic and crude. Go here, click mission, read, watch the dice roll, move on. If there was more interaction while doing the story missions this would make it more exciting. I don't necessarily mind the combat way of doing things, but lets be honest. What are the 10,000 other games out there doing? The exact same thing which is "go here, kill x, talk to y, and get your xp and loot." Diversity of the content and mechanics is desired here. We don't need just another run of the mill combat/mission system. The crew combat system is crude and needs to be fleshed out more. Ship combat is better than crew combat, but I'm certain there's ways of polishing the idea up a bit more. 

Developers, keep up the good work. I am looking forward to seeing more from you.

This game takes some time to get into, as its UI is complicated and the onboarding flow essentially does not exist. Many will bounce off this game for exactly those reasons, but underneath the initial complexity is an intriguing top-down space sim with a huge variety of paths to success. Unlike most games of this genre, ST:F puts a lot of emphasis on the collective skills of your captain,  officers AND crew. Giving you more vectors for customization and specialization of your ship.

Lots of content, slick interrelated systems, responsive and proactive Devs, and a fun story balanced by poor UI, and complete lack of onboarding to help new players.

In my opinion, the good more than outweighs the bad.

37834332.review:
[b]This review was written during the beta, at update #6. I will update it in a few months if things have changed.[/b]

Star Traders Frontier feels a bit like Sid Meier’s Pirates’ big brother, or maybe it is related to Mount and Blade? It has the same free roaming as a lone captain and doing pretty much anything you want, except its bigger, more complex and interesting, but also a whole lot harder, confusing and more often than not plain old frustrating in the way it likes to randomly pit you against impossible odds without even the option to reload your game.

Don’t get me wrong: there is a vast, interesting and complex game in there, I know it. But it is currently hidden behind layers after layers of obtuse mechanics, tentacular interface screens, frustrating minigames and loads of ways of forcing you to restart your game from scratch because you took one bad decision at the end of a 4 hours session, or, even worse, because the RNG decided that yep, that’s it, your time is up. So I cannot in good conscience give Star Traders: Frontiers a positive rating right now.

That was the short version. Below are two long lists of pros and cons if you want more details.


[b]Why the negative review:[/b]

- The UI is a mess. Big useless icons everywhere, menus inside menus inside menus making the simplest of actions take way too many clicks, several buttons on a single screen leading to the same thing, and extremely unintuitive screens that really don’t help you understand what you are looking at. 

- The learning curve is a cliff. Not only is there no tutorial worth mentioning, the tooltips tend to be unexplanatory fluff or just plain not here. So you are left to learn the ropes by trial and error. In a game where ironman is the default and only mode, meaning every “big” mistake you make while learning to play will send you straight back to the title screen or leave you stranded in space.

- Not helping the previous issue, the game starts punishingly hard, and extremely unfair at times, but gets easier and easier as you level up and get better crew and equipment. I know it's a rogue-like, but still, a smoother, handheld start would be welcome.

- Difficulty levels don’t matter nearly as much as they could and probably should. Thanks to the game, er, encouraging me to restart multiple times, I had the opportunity to try 4 out of the 7 difficulty levels. And I really didn’t find much of a difference. You’ll get more XP and take less damage in one, your officers will be able to permanently die in another, sure, but at the end of the day, those are details compared to the game-shattering, half-random circumstances that will lead you to a restart. And yes, ironman is always on, even at the lowest difficulties.

- Some of the minigames manage to be both uninvolving and extremely frustrating. I’m of course talking about the card minigames. It basically goes like this: “Here are 5 cards. One of them is mandatory to advance your (timed!) mission, 2 of them will hurt you badly, and the last 2 will give you a small inconsequential bonus to whatever. Now click on that button and I’ll chose one randomly for you. Too bad ! You lost ! And time is ticking ! Want to try again ?” So, yeah, almost pure luck (some crew skills let you remove a card before the draw, but since you can only use them once per draw, they only mean you now have 1 out of 4 chances to win instead of 1 out of 5). Even worse, that same minigame is recycled everywhere, from orbit patrol to land exploration to spying to finding a black market, here are 5 cards! Click the button ‘til blind luck allows you to resume playing or you run out of time/ressources/patience!

- Hand to hand fighting and space battles are the two other, more fun and involving, minigames. But fighting, and especially fighting in space, against any enemy, will cost you tons of money, lose you characters you’ve been levelling up for hours, and possibly force you to restart the whole game from scratch, all for meager potential rewards. Even when you win a space engagement, the rewards quite often don’t even begin to cover the costs of the repairs or the value of the well-trained crew members you’ve lost. There are health (well, hull) bars in those fights, but since every single enemy shot can kill a crew member (player character included) or damage a vital and costly ship module, they are pretty useless. I won’t pretend there is no strategy involved in those fights. What I will say however is that said strategies can and eventually will be rendered completely moot by a random lucky hit. And the consequences of space battles, win or lose, are so terrible and random that you’ll spend most of the early game actively running away from one of the funniest part of the game because you simply do not have the money reserves to even afford a victory. 

- You are on a timer. Always. You know what I loved about Mount and Blades ? The feeling of freedom. Of being able to go wherever I wanted and do whatever I wanted. And Star Traders really felt that way, at first. Until I realized I would always be on the aforementioned timer. There is a global timer you see, that makes the game harder and harder with time, so you need to constantly improve in an efficient fashion in order to stay competitive. There is also a time limit on every single quest in the game. In fact, said time limits starts ticking when the quest is [i]offered[/i] to you, not when you [i]accept[/i] it. So if you get offered a quest you feel your ship or crew won’t be able to accomplish (for example, [i]anything involving space combat[/i] in the first three years of the game), you can’t postpone it until you are ready : either you accept it right now and wreck your game, or you let it go. And while that’s annoying but acceptable for the randomly generated quests, the same system is also applied to story, pre-written quests, that will only ever show up once in your entire playthrough and, in some case, are automatically “offered” to you (looking at you, Arbitrator/Faen Family questlines), meaning the timer starts without you even asking for it. So either you take up that quest the game thrust on you too soon and you deem impossible in the faint hope of winning it and seeing the rest of the story at the risk of having to restart your whole game if you lose, or you let it go, never to see it again. 


[b]Why I remain hopeful, and plan on coming back to the game in a few months to see where it’s at:[/b]

- The game universe, the background, the writing are top notch. The setting is both believable and rather original, and the story quests are involving and integrate seamlessly in the procedurally generated world. Which kind of make the previous point feel even worse, but still.

- In the same way, the mechanics underlying the game are complex and involving. There are dozens of skills, traits and attributes, there is crew morale, there is diplomacy, relationship building, ship upgrading, dynamic interplanetary trading and economics… Behind the clutter of the UI and the frustratingly brutal randomness, there is an extremely detailed, working simulation.

- I played Templar Battleforce, from the same creators, and I loved every minute of it. It could be hard depending on the chosen difficulty, but never felt unfair, frustrating or random : when you lost, it wasn’t for lack of luck, but due to some clear mistakes on your part, and you could always retry your mission. It was complex, but well explained and relatively navigable in its interface. It timed you, but ignoring said timers to play at your own pace only prevented you from acquiring bonuses, it never prevented you from playing or seeing content. So, while these two games are definitely not the same genre, I know the Trese Brothers can produce games that are right down my alley, and I will follow Star Traders in the hope it eventually gets there too.

At the very begining you can design your captain or pick from a template, you also get 4 offciers and bunch of crew members who all specialize in certein areas to help maintain your ship. You can later level up your captain, officers and crew memebers and pick their talents that will help you out in many different ways, such as exploring, trade goods, ship combat, hand to hand combat, missions, discounts on buying ships, repair cost, morale, and other areas as well. When you level up your captain and officers, you can also multiclass them into other professions that help you in many ways in the game. Your crew however can only level in the class they were recruited into, but you can promote them into officers, if your ship allows it. Every ship is allowed a max number of officers, small ships being around 4 to 5, larger ships around 6 or 7, every ship is different, and can be cuztomize in  different ways, so be sure to check them out. This game does have a certain difficulty to it that can really make you frustrated, when you dont understand the basic mechanics, and yes these are basic. In my first 10 hours of playing, I absolutly hated this game so badly I wanted to punch the developers right in the face, all because I couldnt get my head around the Simple basics. Once you level your crew up to pass these ship checks that no longer becomes a problem. Another basic is obviously making money, this may seem difficult at first, cause the early missions dont pay too much at first but they get better and pay a lot more as you do more missions. Trade can seem difficult at the begining as you need to get trade permits to trade the more expensive goods, but once you get these trade permits the cash will literally start flowing in and money no longer becomes a problem. The only problem I had with this game was its lack of content, but then I realize this game is early access and of course its gonna be short on content and the developers are working on more content to be put into the game. Overall I think this game is pretty good and the developers are doing a good job. I hope theres going to be a lot of dlc for this game and cant wait to get it. So be sure to check this game out.

Let's start by saying something, the Trese Brothers should really get more recognition for the love they put in their games, the kind of interaction they have with the players (and not just during EA) and the ability to merge elements from different Settings/sagas to create a familiar yet intriguingly evolving new setting.

Ever wondered what a good WH4k in space game could play? What if you merged it with some Dune's elements? Wonder no more, you have Star Traders: Frontiers, a turn-based/RPG(ish)/space game oozing potential like few others.

It's current state? Well it's an early (very early) build, already playable and enjoyable, if you can get past some very rough aspects (mainly the UI), but rest assured those will get polished, like in every single game these guys released so far.

Amazing what you can achieve in a game "lighter" than 200MB, if you are into EA, this is definitively worth a buy, if you are not... add it to your wishlist and come back at a later date, it won't disappoint you.

37291685.review:
Promising and deep space-trade-combat game. Enjoyed playing it so far but for me there's a few downsides that prevent me from starting over at the moment. Part of it might be it takes time to master a game like this but I am not sure. I compare this game to Battle Brothers a few times, one of my favorite games. There are similarities. 

-->  Not really a reward for all the (crew-) micromanagement. 

It takes time to build your ship and especially your crew. It's not unusual to have a crew of 30+ you need to level up constantly, especially in the beginning). Since they die quickly or lose morale after a fight and quit (even if they win)  I did not grew attached to them like in Battle brothers. They are too generic at the moment. It might work with a smaller crew and a different, less harsh, morale system. The whole skill system is based on a larger crew though. 

--> No sense of control

Even if you are careful not to over extend and get in difficult fights / quests early you might get a few bad fights / failed quests and lose it all very quicly. I did not feel to have any control over these circumstances (RNG). Just to make sure: I played Battle Brothers for countless hours because I always felt my actions and choices mattered despite the RNG elements. 

Since it's early access I hope some of these issues are tackled. I will not go into the the Pro's at the moment but they are plenty. Definitely one of the more interesting games I played recently and look forward to the new updates. Especially the one where you have a chance to get some nice loot after crew combat ;)

Un jeu fort intéressant avec plusieurs bons points. J'apprécie notamment la façon de progresser via des quêtes, des explorations ou des combats (avec des personnages ou le vaisseau). Il est également possible de renommer et de modifier l'apparence des membres de l'équipage et du capitaine (j'aimerais plus de varieté dans les habits mais ça va quand même). 
L'histoire semble riche aussi avec ces factions, ces différentes planètes, ces artefacts, ces différents moyens de résoudre les quêtes (infiltration, corruption, combat, faux papiers...). Il y a aussi plusieurs niveaux de difficulté.

Cela se joue au tour par tour et cela peut prendre de l'ampleur. Les développeurs sont à l'écoute des joueurs et font souvent des mises à jour. Je n'ai pas encore été très loin car je persiste à réussir une certaine quête et j'échoue chaque fois avec soit un combat de vaisseau ou de personnages perdu, ou une ressource critique non trouvée, ou un pnj assassiné. Cela me fait recommencer à chaque fois mais cela doit être possible alors j'insiste. ^^

Les capitaines de Star Traders Frontiers ont de quoi s'occuper et c'est un jeu que je recommande.

37190947.review:
This game is a diamond in the rough.

Do you like those games where you go from point A to point B, engaging in trade? This is a good one of those. It has more challenges than other trade-based games, which is nice, but it also lacks some of the interface (in the rough, as mentioned).

Do you like games where you can engage in piracy and the like? You can go around intimidating and killing merchants and others, but it's not going to be easy - people will go down fighting.

Do you want to be an adventurer going to wild planets and looking for resources you can't sell anywhere because they're totally illegal? Go unleash your inner Indiana Jones (and get caught in a planet-wide lightning storm that leaves half your crew demoralized).

Do you want to stealthily help out your faction win a conflict through espionage? Yup, you can do that too.

In short, there's a lot of options. However, as mentioned, this is a diamond *in the rough*. There's still a lot of improvements to be done, but it still feels like a complete game at this point - it can just become an even better game with more love and care from the devs.

36907678.review:
I love this game. It's such a wonderful starship captain RPG game. This isn't a twitch game. All of the combat is turn-based, somewhat JRPG style. There's a lot traveling around and micro management of your ship and crew. It's a bit like Sid Meier's Pirates, but in space.
In my current save, I'm an Explorer/Spy. My ship is quite small, and I'm skilled for stealth and escape. So I'm not looking for a stand-up fights. I'm in it to prosper around the edges: gather intel, court contacts, look under rocks.

I'm having a blast with the game, even though it has some rough edges. Because it's early access, that is to be expected. But let's talk about early access here as well since, at this point, many people have likely been burned by abandoned early access projects: these devs are in the forums responding to the players, they're on a discord server responding to players, they're updating the game frequently. In short, they're awesome. 

Pros: 
Choose your officers and recruit a crew. Want more options in a space fight? Grab a bunch of pilots and gunners. Want a more military crew for boarding? Recruit more soldiers. Want none of that? Hire exo-scouts, merchants or spies. Your officers and crewmembers all contribute to the type of options you have at your disposal in any given situation.

A lot of character customization options for you and your officers / crew. You can choose the appearance, gender and name of every crew member. They've got their own traits, And as they level up they'll gain various talents and job skills (21 different jobs). Is one of your crew members in possession of exemplary skills and talent? Get rid of your greedy, disloyal quartermaster and promote that crewmember to officer instead!

Play it like a sandbox, or play scripted missions. If you want to run cargo back and forth to make some money, you can. If you want to explore wilderness planets or spy on a faction, you can. Of course if you want to patrol around spoiling for a fight, you can do that too. But if those things get a bit repetitive, talk to your contacts and get some quests.

There is a web of politics and intrigue to navigate as you try to earn enough to keep your crew happy and ship in one piece. When one faction likes you, the others probably don't. You're going to need places to fuel up and repair though, so managing faction relations is a major component of the game.

Procedural universe creation, in case you want a different sandbox to play in!


Cons:
It's early access, so there are some bugs. I've not encountered any crashes yet, however.

The UI isn't always friendly, but they're working on it!

There's no manual at the moment, so it may take a game or two to understand the mechanics (I just figured out what the little dots under the combat talents meant after 10 hours played...).

Neutral:
The game can be difficult at first. Playing on "Normal" is quite challenging. I haven't tried anything harder than that.
I don't see the difficulty as a pro or con as long as each player can find a level that is challenging without being excessively punishing.

Who should get this game:
Anyone who wants to run a starship around and cobble together a trusty core of officers and full crew. Anyone who likes bouncing from planet to planet, trading, doing missions, levelling up skills, random encounters, exploring, and micromanaging their ship/crew/faction relations.

Anyone like me :)

*edited typos

So ... I'm on the negative side of neutral here, but Binary Thumb Choice is Binary.

I genuinely had a lot of fun working through the mechanics and figuring things out - lots of [i]oh, so thaaaaaat's what that does![/i] kinds of moments, and getting more competant at things for new runs had a kind of wonder for me.

At this point I think I've figured out at least 80-90% of the mechanics of this game (not mastering, just ... I know what they are), but as things are now I sadly don't think it will hold my interest. I mean, I want it to, but ...

This is one of those titles that stitches a bigger game out of a variety of smaller minigames, a method that brings [i]Space Rangers[/i] to mind for me at least, though there's no further comparison between the two titles to be made after that. In this game, it basically boils down to 5 RNG-driven minigames that you'll be rotating through to varying degrees as you progress: space travel, ship combat, crew combat, missions, and ... card flipping stuff.

I'll start on that last one - as you can see in the trailer, there's a bit where you're presented with a semi-random selection of 5 cards. You press a button and RNG decides which cards flip over and dissipate and you're left with one card that gives you a bad thing or a good thing or some combat opportunity or whatever. That's the extent of player interaction here, though: you press one button, and some cards flip over. You can try to stack this in your favor through the occasional crew ability ('remove a negative card before flipping') and (I [i]guess?[/i]) maybe stack the RNG more in your favor by stacking up crew attributes, though the mechanics of such aren't clear right now (early access and all). 

But even after all that: button, cards. That's the gameplay here.

And this mechanic is used [b]a lot[/b]. Patrol shipping lanes? Flip some cards. Blockade a planet? Flip cards. Explore wilderness? Flip. Spy on a planet's networks? Cards. Gain access to black market? Flip some more cards.

The crew combat feels like a JRPG-lite where each character has ... one ability. You just spam attacks until things die, and the opponent does the same, and it's a spam race to see who can make the enemy dead first. To be fair, I think I'm probably missing the finer points of this system, but honestly - this stuff is [i]dull[/i].

Ship combat is more enjoyable by far, though still fairly simplistic. You have a variety of abilities (given by your crew) that you can use per move, and you assign weapons to fire, and there's some range mechanic of sorts that determines weapon/tactic availability ... but just about all of this again comes down to RNG.

Missions, which I am straining to define as a minigame here (though I had to strain equally as much to call the card thing a 'game') boils down to basically one text choice followed by some dice rolling to determine if your choice failed or had some benefit ... maybe some ship combat or something similar happens as a result of this.

The overworld/space travel mechanic, to which I'll also tie the inter-world trading mechanics, is a mess of RNG stuff happening all at once; and once you figure out what you're supposed to be doing to manage your fuel and crew and all that, it eventually becomes a very tedious affair of repetitive clicking and decision making.

"Oh, I've traveled from point A to to point B. I land on this planet. *click* I need to buy fuel, because there is literally no reason why I would not want to do this *click click*; now I will pay my crew to prevent them murdering me *click* *click* *click* and send them on some shore leave *click* *click* oh wait I need to click like 15 times to make sure all of them do it I guess *click* *click* *click* *click* *click* *click*; some of them got sick, so I need to go to the doctor tab *click* and heal them all *click*. In the meantime, all this pay and shore leave made my guys level up, so I need to go the status tab *click* and then the crew submenu *click* and filter my crew to show leveling ones only *click* *click* and then click through every single one of them to assign new job levels and assign tasks, even for the junior crew that have a singular job path *click* *click* *click* *click* *click* *click* *click* *click* *click* ........

And when you travel from point B to point C, get ready to do that whoooole thing over again. It's weird, with all the automated RNG in this game already, that I'm wishing they'd automate this stuff more at this point.

As for Trade, in a game called Star Traders, this mechanic feels very disadvantageous, at least at the early stages with the stuff you can trade in. You can fill your trade ship with some sort of commodity at an A+ price, and sell it off at an A+ price on a nearby planet, and feel good about yourself for making a cool $1K in profits - until you realize that the fuel cost you $600, your crew are demanding about $800 in wages, and demanding shore leave to the tune of $200 more. And you can't really trade in more profitable stuff until you buy very, very expensive licenses - in this manner, Star Traders basically funnels you away from trade and into doing the missions. Why travel from point A to B to try and pull off $1000 profit of trade (that gets swallowed by expenses), when I can travel the same distance for a mission that will give me a $22,000 reward? This is probably the most disappointing part for me, because I was keen to try my hand at some trading. I mean, it's in the title ...

At the end of all this, I can only feel that this title is really not geared towards someone like me, and more towards someone with a heavy background in D&D-like games who love them some dice rolling and RNG. If that's you, well, give it a shot.

I thought I'd take a risk on this. There's currently a bug where there's no tooltips on Linux - but I watched a few "Let's Play" videos and thought I'd be able to manage without for the time being. I have to say I was rewarded with a really deep and fun game.

Though it's in early access, this is a surprisingly complete, functional and playable game already.

I've had no crashes so far (~17hrs play), and other than a couple of bugs in the early scripted storylines (which I think are being worked on) it's been a solid experience. There was a bit of learning curve at first - some of the UI needs a bit of work (especially without tooltips!) but once I watched/read a bit to clarify a few things, I had a great time with it.

There's something of the old Sid Meier's Pirates about it - missions, trade, reputation with different factions etc - though there's a whole extra level of personal reputations and depth to the crew, who can each be upgraded, customised and outfitted.

Additionally, it looks like they've been working hard at fixing and improving everything, and the game designers appear to have good form in long-lasting support and development - so I'm really looking forward to see what this is like a few months down the line.

[edit] Just to add, after having a small bug in my game, I posted a bug report - then got a message back 5 minutes later from the devs saying it had been fixed, and offering to repair my save file if I wanted. That's some seriously impressive service. I think that helps to indicate how friendly and committed these guys are, and how much they care about the game they're working on.

36674287.review:
Star Traders is a rpg-strategy hybrid game where you take on the role of a space captain and explore a randomly generated map for fame and fortune.

As with all hybrid games it's hard to classify the game. Playing this reminds me of Sid Meier's Pirates! which I enjoyed a long time ago. 

Some key features of the game:

0) You travel in a spaceship in a universe of systems connected with jumpgates. Each system contain planets you can visit. You experience random encounters in travel and take up missions and make decisions on the planets you visit.

1) Combat is turned based

2) Missions is card based

3) Both Missions and Combat is affected by jobs (classes) and traits (abilities) 

4) Your Captain and Officers and Crews all play an important part in the mix of Jobs and Traits you get and this will heavily impact the outcome of the missions and actions you take

5) You have a very large range of Jobs you can take.

6) There are different ships and modules you can upgrade, you can also equip your crews with different weapons for Land combat

The Pros:

1) The developers have an excellent track for completing and launching their games. I bought this game based off the pleasurable time I had with Templar Battleforce. They are extremely responsive to suggestions on improvements to the game and have issued 4 patches with of bug fixes and improvements in under 2 weeks since EA! Expect a lot of development activity in EA!

2) The game right now is deep enough to have fun with the still evolving gameplay. In EA, it contains enough content and working game systems to shame some indie fully released games.

3) Support them early. Success is the best motivation to a good team in EA! There's a discount that's ending soon =).

Cons:

1) As it's in EA, the documentation is a bit thin. Most of the information is in the forum. The WIKI is still lacking in detailed explainations of some game systems.

2) The game is still evolving and content is still to be fully fleshed out. So expect an uneven experience. You milage may vary, but some may find the free roam + make my own adventure structure of the game off-putting.

3) There's still bugs to be ironed out and UI to be enhanced. 

It's a really good EA title. And the developers are hard at work on this judging from the frequency of the patches. 

Recommended!

36671083.review:
The Good;
- INSANELY deep gameplay for an early access $11 game. Like seriously, it's fucking insane, like, I cannot even start to list all the traits, contacts, reputation etc etc for every single planet / faction in this game. It's utterly insane.
- Tons of different play styles you can go after (ship to ship combat, trade, spying, ground combat etc)
- Nice art style with customizable visual appearence for each crew member along with heavy customization of crew talents / professions and ship gear.
- Did I mention this game is INSANELY deep?

The Bad;
- Learning curve is basically a vertical asymptote. There is NOTHING that explains to you what in the FUCK any of these stats, attributes, debuffs etc mean. Even when designing your captain, there's pretty much zero explanation of what anything is, so you're essentially flying blind through most of the game through trial and error figuring out what crew does what, why you need them etc

- So theres about like 7+ mini games between ship to ship, ground, spy, patrol, MUDD style quests etc. but once again, you have no idea what the rules are or how anything works, so you'll find yourself getting demolished in one of these game modes and you have no idea what you're doing wrong or what you should even try to do to not suck.

- Although the game is insanely deep, none of that complexity really DOES anything. You basically just fly around progressively longer distances having the same random events occur where you either choose to fight the ship or just run away. And there's like almost no reason to fight the ships because you lose reputation and will rack up hefty repair bills, have crew die etc. So the game becomes really boring as you click from warp-gate to warp-gate, having to stop every so often to refuel and pay your crew on a planet somewhere.

- Unrelated to the above, the story elements that do exist are pretty weak and the script for the text base conversations is pretty painfully bad, you will skip all every single time.

- RNG for losing crew and stuff is probably a little *too* steep as it stands now. I had high levels crew leave because I didn't land intime to pay them because I was doing whatever, and after like spending the entire game on my ship they bounce. Worst part is there's no like progress bar for when you have to pay your crew, so you're just blindly stopping at planets trying to pay them everytime you can. Plus the game CONSTANTLY auto rolls anytime your ship is moving for bad shit to happen to you and your crews skills / talents are the only thing that stop it, but bad shit will still happen because of RNG. I think it'd be a bit nicer if you had a chance of some beneficial RNG to happen to mix it up instead of just wondering when there's gonna be some sort of electronics explosion or w/e that mames half your crew while you're running for you life from a pirate.


IN CONCLUSION / TL:DR
Game is undeniabley INSANELY complex, with a learning curve that more akin to a brick wall. After spending 7-8 hours messing around, I can say the game has a TON of potential moving forward. But as it stands now it needs a LOT of tweaking to make it live up to that potential.

Things it needs before I'd recommend someone buying it;
- A decent tutorial for the different game modes to explain the basic rules so you don't keep losing crew b/c you don't understand wtf is happening

- MOTHER FUCKING TOOLTIPS for stats etc to give you an idea of what % increase or decrease in whatever it provides

- Tweaking gameplay to involve less fetch / deliver and more ground / space combat / spying etc. It's incorperated to the story based missions but like 75% of the auto generated missions are fetch quests.

- Did I say some decent fucking tutorials and some tool tip explanations?

36656318.review: I normally stay away from early access because I prefer a "finished" game.  Something about this caught my attention and I am glad I took a chance on it.  The game still needs to flesh out the content and improve some quality of life issues but it is already in better shape than some "finished" games I have played in the past and updates have been common since I started playing.  This is a fairly straight forward turn based game where you create a ship captain as an avatar but includes both ships officers and crew.  The officers and crew offer different options in various situations and need to be managed and levelled to make the most effective team while the size of the team is dictated by your current ship.  Game play includes various missions that have a large RNG outcome (5 different outcomes selected randomly based on the mission that you see before choosing to proceed in what I have seen so far) that can be influenced by captain, officer, and crew skills and combat that consists of ship to ship and 4 on 4 crew battles.  Where the game offers some great twists is the Captain template character creator and the faction/contact mechanic.  The Captain template allows you to trade off different aspects of your starting character by requiring you to rank different categories which dictates the available pool you get to invest in that category so some tradeoffs are required.  If you want the best possible starting ship you need to sacrifice somewhere else.  The faction/contact mechanic dictates which missions are available, upgrades and bonuses, and some services that are available in star ports.  The contacts have both personal interactions and faction interactions that can change during the game and through your actions which provides some added consequence to many of the random encounters and missions throughout the game.  Overall I am very pleased with the game so far and if you enjoy turn based RPG’s with consequences to your actions then give this a try.

36655215.review:
Something about this game compels me to play it-- to learn more about its inner workings; to figure out the best strategy to stay afloat.  But at every turn, it beats me down with nonsensical and unexplained game mechanics, confusing UI layouts, some painful repetition, and where are the hotkeys to make any of this more palatable?

But of course, this is EA.  So I can't really blame the incomplete thing for being incomplete.  I can only hope that it gets better over time so that I don't have to resort to writing batch files to manage my save games as I agonizingly gain glimpses into its mechanics through sheer trial and error.

Things that would make this experience more palatable right now:
1) Documentation.  The tooltips from your officers are not sufficient.  Combat traits and personal weapons are full of undocumented limitations that prevent their usage in certain situations.  A multitude of ship equipment has undocumented functionalities.  

2) UI.  Ship movement and map dragging should not use the same button.  I noticed you even programmed movement to be both right and left click, while map dragging only uses the left mouse button.  Just leave ship movement to the right mouse button alone.  Also, leveling up is pretty agonizing.  Instead of making me click on the spice interface, then into my ship details, then into my character list, and then filtering my character list on newly-leveled characters, just give me a button to look at my new leveled characters straight from the spice interface.  And give us hotkeys for all of these actions-- inform us what they are through tooltips.  And while you offer sorting characters on a few conditions, why didn't you offer sorting on HP or MP?  And those random events that tick off constantly during space travel... I don't care if I passed or failed a roll.  I care what actually happened.  Did my officer hide our emissions, preventing a nearby ship from detecting us?  Let me know.  Did my helmsman spill water on his console, electrocuting himself?  Let me know that too.  

3) Mechanics.  Reinforced Armor 4 on my ship claims to add 45% to my armor, yet it raised my ship's armor from 6 (Block 26%) to 20 (Block 54%)... what is going on?  And no amount of deflector arrays (or anything else I can figure out) will raise my shields at all from 3 (Block 8%).  Character attributes... how do they affect anything?  There's no feedback to tell me which crew benefit from which attributes.  There's no way for me to know if I'm better off equiping Meshed Body Armor, Plated Combat Armor, or even Grey Ops Meshing: it says I need it adds "+8 Stealth Evasion (req's skill)" with a green hood icon.  What skill does it require?  Stealth?  Evasion?  Green hood?  Telepathy?  Patience?

All she needs is a little polish.  Make this thing actually playable for a first-timer.  Keep at it.

36641069.review:
Un très bon jeu en devenir. Le jeu est en accés anticipé, pour l'instant pas mal de features ne sont pas encore implémentées, mais les bugs sont très peu nombreux et le jeu est parfaitement jouable en l'état. De plus les développeurs sont réactifs et très attentifs aux retours des joueurs.

Le jeu est un sandbox spatial avec une très forte composante RPG. Vous incarnez le capitaine d'un vaisseau dont la taille varie de la corvette jusqu'au croiseur. le jeu déroule en 2D, vue de dessus de votre vaisseau dans l'espace. Vous naviguez de planète en planète, chaque arrêt vous permettant de vous ravitailler, de commercer, de réaliser des missions, voire d'autres activités comme explorer, espionner, faire des patrouilles ou des blocus. Lors de vos voyages, vous pouvez rencontrer d'autres vaisseaux, pirates ou marchands, pouvant éventuellement dégénerer en combat spatial. 

Dans cet univers où une dizaine de factions se partagent et se disputent le contrôle de l'espace connu, vous êtes libre de mener la carrière que vous souhaitez. Marchand, officier militaire au service d'un clan, contrebandier, pirate sans foi ni loi, le choix vous appartient.

Votre capitaine ainsi que chacun de vos (nombreux) membres d'équipage est un PNJ avec ses statistiques et ses compétences propres, que vous gérez individuellement. Pilotage du vaisseau, combat au sol ou activités annexes comme l'espionnage ou la contrebande, à chacun sa spécialité et il vous appartient de gérer la balance au sein de votre vaisseau. De fait, on s'attache à son petit monde, et si la perte d'un simple mousse ne vous ennuiera pas plus que ça, le décès de votre maître espion/hacker vous arrachera un râle de désespoir, en plus de vous faire perdre des compétences précieuses!

Un jeu passionnant à essayer si ce style de jeu vous intéresse!

Correction, 22.11.2017

I dont know what to think about this game. >> No, I do now.
It's still EA, so maybe it changes for the better. >> That may be possible. The Dev seems really dedicated to the game, so maybe things change. But for my part, I won't be waiting for it.

I have played previous titles of the devs (Templar Battleforce is actually pretty good - Heroes Of Steel not so much). At the moment it suffers from the same problems as the previous titles: 
The game mechanics are not explaind. It appears the devs don't at all care whether you understand how to play their game and how the mechanics work or not.

More specifically:
You get no idea how a character's attributes and skills affect performance. It is not explained. At all.
You see regular rolls in a little window on the lower right, but there is no explanation what they mean, how they affect your ship, your crew, whatever. You have no chance of understanding what is going on nad how affect that is going on.
Crew members get hurt, but you only know that when you receive a warning their health is low. Why that happens, how it could be prevented, you just won't know, the game won't tell you. 
You find yourself suddenly with crew members gone. You don't why, or maybe you might, if you could look it up in that little window, if messages hadn't been so small and passed by so quickly, you just didn't notice (and because other windows were on top of it).

I have given the game a few more hours to win me over. I wanted to like this game, but eventually came to the conclusion that the game mechanics are so opaque that it is just frustrating.
You have to make decisions in the game, but the game gives you no basis to found your decisions on. You cannot make informed decisions, because you dont get information (or none that makes any sense).

Another thing that is extrmeley frustrating: Your character may train in three jobs, which improve certain skills. So if at some point you want to learn another skill, that's just not part of one of the three jobs, too bad, you can't. Riiiiight. That makes sense. I cannot learn how to use a rifle, because... well, I have three jobs and none of them includes rifle. On the other hand, since the game doesnt explain to you how a skill affects rolls, it doesnt really matter, does it? 

Also to everyone who thinks about buying this game: BE WARNED. YOU CANNOT SAVE.
All progress is saved automatically and immediately for you. There's no going back. You didn't understand how a roll works and couldnt make an informed decision? Too bad, live with the consequences of not knowing what you're actually doing. 

The - by now informed - decision I made: I stopped playing. Too bad that I decided to give the game a second chance instead of getting a refund while I still could, but I really really hoped there could be a good game hiding somewhere underneath, because I so much wanted to have a game that felt like the old Traveller RPG and I felt that this was exactly what the game strived to be. Too bad the implementation is just... very very bad.

36625573.review:
I want to love Star Traders: Frontiers.  It takes the mythos Trese Brothers have been building from the original Star Traders through Templar Battleforce and builds upon it.  The moment I saw the KickStarter for this game, I knew I'd back it.  That's how much I believe in the setting and Trese Brothers in general.

The universe is rich and vibrant, the artwork and music are solid, and the UI is easy to work with, once you learn it.  I like the sense of depth they've given all the crewmembers you pick up (primarily through traits that influence what improves or detracts from their morale rating).  The attention to detail with regard to ship operations and crew relations is wonderful, but still manages not to overwhelm the player with minutae.  The main narrative is well made, too, and I'm impressed how they've managed to make the sandbox missions impact it. The card games to simulate Patrols, Spying, Exploration, and the like are a nice twist, too. To wit, there's a lot to like about this game.

And yet, I can't recommend it unreservedly, but I must add a caveat:  this game is unforgiving.  One wrong move, one spate of bad luck in a combat, one random encounter that goes south, and you can go from "Hey, I'm doing pretty well" to "Welp, better start a new character because I'm screwed six ways to Shalun".  If you run out of money (and it's a probability on 3 to 5 hyperjump missiions, especially if you have to go through a hostile sector), your problems snowball quickly.  I've gone through three characters already, and I've been playing on Basic difficulty (the lowest setting).  Don't get me wrong, I'm not looking for a cakewalk.  I'd just like to be able to recover from misfortunes when they occur.  

To that end, I humbly ask the developers to maybe make paying missions a little less hard to come by.  In the original Star Traders, you had at least the possibility of finding gainful employment in every port (either from the Palace or the Spice Hall, sometimes from the military wing of the Spaceport).  In Frontiers, if you run out of money multiple jumps away from your nearest contact, you're looking at several crew mutinies and a ship damaged from hyperjumps without fuel before you can get a new mission, and then you have to do the mission before you get paid (requiring more flying, mutinies, and ship damage).  When you finally do get paid, you have crew wages, fuel costs, repair costs, doctor bills, and rounds in the spice hall to buy before you're back to where you were (and chances are, you didn't get paid enough to cover all of those expenses).  Those are all reasonable consequences of failure in the Star Traders universe, mind you, but only being able to get paying work in a tiny fraction of everywhere you can travel makes it more arduous than IMHO it ought to be.

So, to sum up: I like this game and would still recommend it to fans of sci-fi RPG games in genral and Trese Brothers fans in particular.  I just don't *love* it, at least not yet.  A few anti-frustration features would go a long way toward helping me love it.

Rating: 3.5 out of 5

36617798.review:
Edit: I'm changing my initial review from tentative thumbs up to full endorsement, this game is great, it's devs are great, it has proven a highly enjoyable distraction to come back to even if it has the odd rage quit WTF moments. 

This game is one of those ambitious titles that seeks to be a little of everything, it's a lot like a mash up of Darkest Dungeons,  Sunless Sea (in space) and possibly Stardew Valley in the sense of combining so many elements. The core mechanics of the game itself seem largely stable and could progress into becoming a sensationally good game. The devs are constantly at work to update, balance, fix or add new content based on gamer feedback. 

Pros: Music is nice, writing is pretty good, game is mostly stable with very few bugs encountered. Large amount of depth, clearly the game is designed to be very expansive in what the final product will deliver an example would be the trading system which takes politics into account, house and faction trade bans which will affect your rep and so on. 

Things in the middle: Graphics, given that it's definitely an indie style game one isn't expecting great works of art but the things they do have could use some definite polish. 

Edit: The character models have been improved and general graphics are now in the realms of good.

Cons: The mini game mechanics for a lot of the ingame missions or quests could do with a lot of work. You're constintently stuck with 'dice rolls' where you have no ability to influence the outcome which has led to 25 mission failures on a storyline mission for which my captain is supposed to be a specialist in their field. This is really the part that makes me want to go away and come back in a few months to see if it's better, this design makes it constantly an unsatisfying grind to achieve anything. Also as you fly through space you are bombarded with skill checks which don't show why there was a skill check, failing intimidation every time you go past a planet and not knowing what exactly that means or how it affects your ship and crew gets old quite quickly.

Edit: A lot of these complaints in the cons are either improved or fixed, the mini games are still quite simplistic with little interaction involved but that in itself has a certain charm and the fail rate for storylines has been largely fixed it seems. About the only big con for me personally is the lack of a save game option because maybe just maybe you don't feel like restarting your level 20 captain who was doing really well until that set of unfortunate occurences deep in hostile space...

[b]NOTE:[/b] Early access review after four or five hours play.

[u]Summary:[/u] A deep and complex top down sandbox sci-fi RPG involving many dice rolls and card based events, with lots of influences from the likes of Firefly, Dune and WH40K, slightly troubled by garish design and an occasionally weak or irritating interface.  If you like the genre and like supporting indie devs there's tons of gaming value to be had here.

I suspect I'll be sinking a good few hours into this title, I haven't even scratched the surface yet.

[u]Pros:-[/u]

+ Complex and engaging RPG design with multiple characters (you, officers, crew), each with multiple classes, skills / perks and levels.
+ Lots of design choices when it comes to upgrading your ships and character loadouts.
+ Free form play with plenty of avenues to explore and exploit - trading, piracy, smuggling, spying, going off the beaten track to explore and so on.
+ What looks to be an interesting and engaging main plot arc (that I haven't got very far into yet), with the promise from the devs of lots more to come.
+ Interesting reputation and faction systems to navigage.
+ Even the low difficulty levels are challenging.
+ A very helpful community, particularly on Discord with responsive devs who obviously care passionately about their game.  As an example I pointed out a bit of friction in the GUI and one of the devs came back five minutes later and said "just changed the code, it will be fixed in the next patch".  In some ways quite minor, but that responsiveness to something that will eliminate hundreds of unecessary mouse clicks from any one game playthrough impressed me.

[u]Cons:-[/u]

- The depth and complexity isn't always matched by an interface that makes things accessible.  Most of it can be figured out but you need to work at it (having to work at an interface means, imho, that something's not right).  Some of this may be caused by the fact that the game has been designed for multiple platforms.  Still, as noted above, the devs are aware of some of the criticism here and very responsive to ideas about how to improve things.
- I think I'll get my head around most of the gui quirks, eventually, but in a perfect world I wouldn't have to.
- Occasional opacity or lack of feedback eg I buy commodity X on a planet for n% less than the galactic average and take it to a planet where demand should be high, but can only sell at a loss.  There may be many reasons for this, but I haven't found a way to find out what they are. 
- Obviously a personal opinion but I find the bright colours used everywhere to be too garish for my tastes.
- Similarly I'm not a huge fan of the cartoonish nature of the art but a) I can see past that and b) we're talking about an indie studio so expecting Star Wars Battlefront II levels of prettiness would be ridiculous.

36590782.review:
Star Traders is a complicated space faring sandbox that proved addictive despite some tedium and weak UI.
   In a fractured galaxy, the player character has inherited the writs to authorize him/her to become a star trader, an independent explorer/trader/pirate/privateer. Then the game pretty much lets you go. You are given an initial mission to begin the narrative, but you are free to ignore it if you'd rather just explore.
   Both ground and space combat is similar to Darkest Dungeon, except not quite as pretty or intricate. Exploration and misc orbital activites are resolved through a card draw. Skill and talent checks (such as diplomatic actions) are resolved by dice rolls. Every action is influenced by the skills of your captain, officers, and crew. The development of this crew and their impact on your adventures was one of my favorite aspects. Crew skills are constantly being checked to influence events and actions. This selection and development of your large crew allows for some emergent gameplay.
   My complaints would be the occaisonally weak UI and time consuming maintenance. The game doesn't elaborate on why there are constant skill checks or what the consequences are. Tooltips are sparse at best. Your ship and crew require frequent maintenance that you must authorize manually. I would love to see the UI given some love and options for automated maintenance to be added, at least for the easier difficulties.
   Overall, Star Traders is an ambitiuos game that doesn't always hit it's mark, but is close enough to provide (presumably many) hours of playable space drama.

(Reviewed for EA Version 2.0.7)
Do I recommend this game? By all the fun gods: Yes!

Star Trader is essentially a space sim that neatly falls between the two typical lines of the genre, that is:
1) Hand-held, berates you for even thinking about deviating from the safety zone until you've traded hours of your soul away for the scrap tier fighter.
2) No direction, but you better grind tedium if you want any hope to live.

Star Trader gives you every option a captain could want without forcing you onto one path.  Heck you could even do many things at once, for while the game does recommend trading goods - you can right out the gate get stuck into mischief, profitting from the misfortune of your rival factions - or even independents - while cozying up with your faction of preference.  There is risk, but that's half the fun!

^ Edit2: Just for the record: Entirely possible on Brutal difficulty - one from the hardest - Ironman. :3

Synopsis is as follows; bear in mind this isn't a comprehensive list:

PROS
1. Absolute Freedom of Style - Fighting things early game? Is profitable and fun!
2. Neat Artwork Style (Though some models do look mutated or way too smug, hmm...)
3. Engaging Combat System, made better by a delightful OST as well.
4. Intriguing storyline that does a good job of easing you into the game-world, both as tutorial and lore guide, and avoids being overly patronizing on either count.
5. Very Active Dev Support - this cannot be overstated enough, most OP postive really. :)

QUIRKS - May be CONS
1. Worse morale than the Imperial Guard; your crew *will* desert you until you have enough Commander skilled officers to keep them in line.  This can seriously impair your early game fighting ability, with enough bad rolls it can end a run prematurely. For whatever reason, spice does little to stem the pain either, how dare they be clean.  Also the Captain has the worst morale recovery ever, period.

2. Spontaneous Major Health Fail RNG.  Could just be bad rolls, but are the full health crew playing with scalpels and baking in radiation while we're travelling? Those hospital trips aren't cheap!

X (Reviewer Derp). Trading - This segment has proven slanderous to the name of Shalun.  Redacted; spice is also off the menu tonight, bad reviewer. :P

CONS
1. Possessive Rename UI.  If you ever want to rename your crew into a more easily trackable roster, be prepared to spend 20 minutes wrestling with the game.  This is not an exaggeration.
2. No quick map references when taking contracts, having to exit the planet and everything eats a small amount of fuel, no big loss but it is annoying when all you want to do is check if you're heading 29 AU west, or north.  If there is a way already, it's not easily identifable.
3. Hotkey tooltips could stand for some display speed improvement, maybe even a config list.

See! Even when bad-mouthed this game doesn't come off so bad.  Still, ultimately the choice is up to you gamers if this is your cup of spice coffee.  Shalun favours the brave!

Edit - Fixing American to English.  Nothing important.

36585903.review:
An early access game that shows a lot of promise and still has a lot of deep gameplay mechanics at this stage in lifestyle. Definitely worth the sub-$20 pricetag.

Things I like:
-In depth crew simulation, with over a dozen classes, and their effectiveness is tied to the overall type of captain you're trying to be (trader, pirate, etc), as well as the type and tech level of the ship components you use, In each game, you're managing a handful of officers and literally 2 dozen crew members as they level up and gain talents every 3 levels or so.

-In depth individual class, each class has a unique set of talents which are all gamechangers. Each class has something like 12 unique talents.

-In-depth ship management, with over 75% of ship being modular - you can change out cargo bays, weapons, sensors, crew quarters, brig, armor plating, weapon lockers, fuel bays, for each other and a variety of other components.

-In-depth contact/mission simulation - where a contact is a person who gives you missions, as well as 1-5, out of maybe 20, other things, such as missions, black market access, trading permits, bounty permits, pardons, introductions to others, discounts, special gear and special crew. The missions also vary widely depending on what contact you use, and if you are a trader and going to a military officer for attack contracts, you won't really have to the skills to succeed; similarly, a bounty hunter, unless specially built for non-bounty missions, won't do well on intelligence missions that require a lot of stealth and quickness, and you will fail skill checks and have the agent you were supposed to smuggle onto a planet discovered because you couldn't sneak past the port authorities

-In-depth faction reputation mechanics - each action you take is affects a variety of factions in a logic fashion. Patrol and find an enemy pirate - gain rep with the faction that controls the area. Blockade and intercept a merchant in the same area - lose rept

-Open world with a variety of ways to make money. You aren't forced into missions, and trading is very lucrative. You can also go exploring uninhabitated worlds, go spy and sell intel for income, you can smuggle, you can pirate, you can go bounty hunty, you can mine resources

-The beginnings of a promising story arc. The game's in early access, so the story isn't done yet, but it is filled with interesting decisions.

In short, I love the game. Thank you devs!

36579351.review:
I bought this game having never heard of the developer or their other titles before. So far, I have been very impressed. 

THE GOOD:

- Incredible variety of customization options for both your ship, your captain, and your crew. Not just how they look, but all their gear, their traits, their talents, and more.

- The game encourages a variety of playstyles and they all actually work:  I have restarted six times so far due to my own failures and have played as a bounty hunter, a merchant, a pirate, and a silver-tongued diplomat. You can mix and match roles and change your focus at any time, and your crew can be tailored to support your captain's weaknesses. There are many jobs I still have not gone deep with that I am looking forward to trying.

- Very interesting relationship mechanics where you have to be introduced to contacts to receive missions, equipment, or favors from them. When you begin, you only have two or three contacts available, but by the time I failed my latest play-through, I had more than twenty and had barely scratched the surface of exploring the galaxy.

- Challenge! As I've mentioned, I've failed six times for multiple reasons (usually because I get too greedy while in a sector of the galaxy where I have no allied stations/planets to land at). There is only Ironman mode with no saving, which keeps me from being the save-scumming baby I usually am and makes the game much more tense and amplifies mistakes. I have not felt frustration from these failures as restarting is not painful, but I have yet to invest many hours into a single playthrough, either.

- The developer so far has been very active with addressing and fixing bugs. I submitted one through their forums and it was fixed the same night.


THE BAD:

- The UI is currently clunky. I could not figure out how to move the map with my mouse for several hours, for instance. I expected moving the cursor to the edge of the screen would scroll it in that direction as is typical in 4X games, but it does not. I eventually figured out that you are meant to click and drag. Additionally, at some battle conclusion screens, I had details/options that ended off the edge of my screen and I expected scrollbars to appear so that I could access those. They did not and again it took me several hours before I realized you could click and drag there. The UI could do a better job of making it obvious how to navigate through it. The developer has made some very good strides here already, but more can be done.

- Lack of a useful tutorial. When I was first dropped in the game, I had no idea what I was doing and I stil have only a basic understanding of some systems. The wiki is informative, but I would like to see more of this information in game.


OVERALL:

I've already played the hell out of this game and have zero regrets with buying it. If you like sandbox games, I cannot recommend this enough.

36578662.review:
My early impressions are based upon a short amount of time playing (6 hrs) and watching about 10 hours of you tube videos on the game play. 

From my perspective, when you mix a variety of spaceships with manageable stats governed through upgradeable components, 30 or more characters with thier own stats, skills, talents, equipment and they level all served on a platter of procedurally generated systems within lots of quardrants, you have just created the recipe for a banquet of RPG game potential to rival all other games of the gendre.

Add in the difficulty settings, random events, a story line, missions, factions, galactic trading, and contacts/diplomancy and this banquet is now a cornucopia of potential.

However, the game is seasoned with "Rogue-lite", which depending on your expectations might be too spicy or not spicy enough for your tastes.

I was expecting primarily an RPG with Rogue-lite elements (limited save/load options, procedurally generated content, random RNG unfairness geared towards a quick and possibly unrecoverable setback); but, what I got instead was an experience that more closely resembled a Rogue-lite with many RPG elements geared towards a quick unrecoverable demise and forced restart as is common for Rogue-like games.

Upon doing some further research, the game does not deviate from its design. It excels in sticking to its intent. Although, there are some UI refinements that would make gameplay for new players less confusing, I believe that I will be play this game for many hours and highly recommend it to those who are looking for an in depth Rogue-like game.

I especially applaud the high level of developer interaction with the player community and thier desire to quickly squash any bugs and to tweak the game to make it a better gaming experience.

36561245.review:
*Disclaimer* I was a kickstarter backer and also an Alpha tester for this game. This is not a sponsored nor endorsed review. I received my Steam key for Early Access on November 16th, 2017 that was accounted for by my backing tier on Kickstarter. Please do not let the amount of time shown played be a real reflection of the 30+ hours I have already put into this game. 


     Have you ever read a good science fiction book, watched a engaging sci-fi TV show, or been into a riveting movie so much that you wish you were there? With this game, Star Traders: Frontiers from Trese Brother Games, now you can.  This may seem like a game you have played before, but it has a few new tricks up its sleeve. An ambitious game that seems nearly improbable for a team of just 3 to pull off, Frontiers is the direct sequel to 2009's Star Traders RPG on Android/iOS/Amazon for mobile. This is the 5th game in the series and shows how much detail that TB have added to their lore in addition to their coding and art skills. If you liked the first game and/or have played Elite, Lightspeed, and other "Space Traders sims"; you will most assuredly find a lot to love here.  

     Each new captain you create will have their own career story. You may choose not to follow the tutorial storyline, but it is there for you to get a better grasp on the mythos that TB have painstakingly worked on. You will captain an entire ship full of crew that aren't just drones. Each person in this game has their own motivations and character growth. You decide how to shape them in addition to your captain as you all face the Frontiers of a new galaxy together. There are lots of choices and even more things to customize.  You'll be surprised at what might just be possible. 

     It has to be stated that there is no wrong way to play this game. It can also be seen as a rogue-lite in some comparisons...especially at the higher difficulties. Be prepared to lose captains somewhat often in earlier difficulties and most assuredly in the highest ones. There is a growing Wiki for information for new players and veterans alike. This game is not set in stone and as with their other games, TB will certainly continue to support this game for quite a long time to come.  {as I was typing this, they posted an update for ST:RPG. That level of loyalty and compassion is missing from most devs and especially on an android app that is nearly 9 years old.)

     Finally, please know that their community is one of the safest and most fun communities around. They have worked even harder on their community than on their games and it shows. You can reach either dev on most days in the forums, on their discord, or other avenues. They are always willing to talk to fans, answer questions, accept bugs found, and have even been known to take player suggestions into the game. 
Finally, you will never find any P2W Microtransactions, nor even any loot boxes ever. 

     My name is LordofSyn. I am a staunch supporter of the Trese Brothers and their games since I found them years ago on Android. I would love to see other dev teams, big and small, match the level of success and the level of communications with their fan base as the Trese Brothers have and continue to do day in and day out. I also post Let's Plays of many of their games and have a current series for this game too. Please see the playlist below and the following daily streams. 
Happy Gaming!
