36537593.review:
These guys have a lot of chutzpah. I guess they didn't get the message that said two brothers shouldn't undertake such an ambitious project that trangresses and remixes many of the traditional genres to create an epic sandbox space trading rpg set in an evolving almost 4X like universe that has a life of it's own far beyond the actions of a single captain. Whether they didn't get the message or just refused to heed it is a very good thing, because they've succeeded amazingly with the initial release of Star Traders Frontiers.

Seriously who hasn't been playing an RPG and just wished that they could quit the story and go for a romp around the world and still have fun and progress and influence the outcomes of various events from a different angle, and then maybe pick up the story again after it's progressed some without you. STF offers that and so many other ways of playing and engaging the with world that it's hard to believe it can all be held together. The game manages to bust the boundaries and yet it still provide an environment that will demand a high-level of focus from the player in order to accomplish whatever goals they're pursuing. 

Having played the game considerably in the alpha stage, it's worth saying that this, like other deep games, requires the player to take some time to learn to swim. It's not one that you pick up and immediately know how to play. It is, however, definitely worth the investment to figure it out. Playing in Early Access you've also got the opportunity to help influence the further development of the game and work out this kinks that aren't working for you. These developers are probably the most responsive devs to their community and if something is working, or fully implemented right now, you can be sure that they will get it smoothed out, sometimes in 24 hours, sometimes a bit longer ;). 

Either way I can't wait to see what this game will be like when it reaches full maturity. Is it too early to start throwing around words like "a legend" or "epic?"

36536335.review:
This game. First its a Trese Brothers game. These guys do WORK. Templar Battleforce, SteelHeroes RPG, Star Traders 4x, etc. etc. We are talking about updates that are FREE, and last about as long as Paradox updating. We are talking YEARS of polishing, free updates, a fantastic community, and a downright amazing developer response time. These guys are up there with Soldak, CD Projekt RED, and Spiderweb software when it comes to amazing post-release support. Templar Battleforce recieved a rediculous amount of content and is to this day one of my favorite Space-Hulk/XCOM type games.

So what are you getting with this title, its current release, and future plans. First, lets discuss what the game is. You are a space trader. Its a 2D top-down strategy game where you fly around, accept missions, trade goods, fight pirates, and generally whatever you want to do. All while maintaining your ship, your crew, and your rep with the various space factions. Escape Velocity Nova, Space Rangers 2 HD, Endless Sky, Oolite, Star Nomad 2, all do similar things. So what ELSE are you getting? ST:F offers a living, breathing galaxy. Not quite X3:Terran Conflict, but far more than Freelancer. You have warring factions, blockades, contacts for missions who you build relationships or play against one another.

Then you have the crew. Your crew consists of regular joes who help on the ship or in combat. Your officers are like the captain and can have 3 jobs, everyone gets levels and talents. Which is good, because space is dangerous. I'm not just talking starship destruction. Crew in-fighting, sickness, mutiny, all kinds of things can go south very quickly, which is manageable with said talents everyone gets. Think Sid Meier's Pirates. You don't leave port without a time limit. Same applies here, fuel, supplies, etc all play a part in day to day life. You are managing a ship and crew. You are a star-captain. Act like it.

In the game's current state its missing some story content, but you've got a big galaxy to roam around in, working faction interactions, and a rediculous amount of things to do. Want to Spy for a faction? ok. Pirate traders? Sure thing. Hunt down bounties? No problem. Explore new planets and get into combat? Absolutely.

Combat in this game is turn based. So your ship moves toward the enemy ship, and you choose what weapons to fire or talents to use. Ground/Boarding Party combat is .... well it reminds me of a Darkest Dungeon-lite. You assign 4 positions and it plays out a bit like an rpg. Talents and weapons play a key role here.

The game is polished and playable right now. However, Trese Brothers is OUTSTANDING when it comes to content addition, and polishing of their game. If their past titles are any indication they will still be tweaking and perfecting this sandbox gem years from now.

Ever watched Firefly? Smugglers V, Endless Sky, and Space Rangers 2 not doing it for you? Give this a try. Its fast becoming my favorite 2d Sid Meier's Pirates clone. So much going on here, and as they add more story and sandbox features I can't imagine it not becoming one of the best of its kind.

It also runs on potatoes. Like an actual potatoe. Out of the ground. With no electricity, and it has an AMAZING price. The fact that you don't own it already hurts me like when you bought Pixel Privateers and Star Nomad 2. Or when you pre-ordered Star Sector. This game rocks. If you like space, crew/ship management and making your own way among a vibrant and living universe with Warhammer 40k esque lore, than you owe it to yourself to own this game.

Sounds like a paid review huh? Well there are some downsides. The UI needs a bit of work, but I prefer it to say Star Nomad 2. The game can feel a little barebones if you are new to this type of game, and have no idea how to make it up from nothing in a crap ship. Its a bit grindy, (granted this genre is much like JRPG's.) and frankly it could use more weapon and ship types. However, again, I have had nothing but great experiences with Trese Brothers.

As someone who freaking adores open ended ship trading/fighting games, from New Horizons mod, to Elite Dangerous, to  Escape Velocity Nova(Endless Sky.), I have been playing this type of game for the last decade or so. Constantly looking for the one that was perfect for me. Space Rangers 2 was close, but it lacked crew. EV: Nova was close, but it again lacked people aboard my ship. (and the combat was tedious.) I only have a few hours after work and family, and I'm playing this game. In a golden age of video games, media, and my other hobbies, I still find myself thinking about my next captain and the strategies it will take to thrive in Hard mode. It already is very good, and with the quality I expect out of Trese Brothers, I expect it to become great.

Christ. You read all that? You must really not be sure. Take it from me. This game is worth your time. Not buggy. Fun, and will have lots of content upon full release. Plus its one of the most polished EA's Ive ever played, and the community actively gets responses from the developer. Get on it.

36519752.review:
A rich game, which adapts to many different playstyles. You have to manage your crew (its health and morale and its varied attributes, skills, talents, and traits), but your goals are your own. You can play the great game (politics) for all it’s worth, or focus on trade, legal or not, or spy, or prey on merchants, or protect them from pirates, or land and explore.

You don’t have to fight, but if you do, you’ll discover that ship combat and crew combat each are their own game. For crew combat, for instance, you decide which of your fighters join the fray and in which relative positions; then, each turn, you decide which talents they use among those you had them learn (like your captain, your officers and crew improve with experience).

The paths you can take are as numerous as the stars, and no aspect of the game feels half-baked or shallow. Even after the many hours I played during the alpha stage, I was left with plenty to try—and that was before the stories were added!

Sounds overwhelming? It could be. It isn’t. If you try to excel at everything from the get-go, you’ll find it tough, but if you focus on what interests you most, you’ll learn what you need as you go. Plus, the newly added stories will take you by the hand, at first, and make sure you both learn the ropes and discover the lore of the Star Traders universe.

I can hardly wait to have more time to play!

36519383.review:
Disclaimer: I am a moderator on the Trese Brothers’ Discord Server, and was a closed Alpha playtester. I recived my key from backing the Kickstarter. 

Star Traders: Frontiers is primarily a game about a single Captain, their ship, their loyal Officers and their crew. The gameplay is primarily sandbox oriented, with the player being able to freely move from world to world, trading in the Exchanges, exploring the vast untamed Wild Zones, Spying for precious intel, fighting in the silence of the void or chasing down criminals in a gravity well. However, every choice made comes with consequences, be they good or ill. Crew, Officers, and even the Captain can and will die in battle or in unforgiving wilderness. The Factions do not treat lawbreakers kindly, and beware the terror of the Xeno. 

The story is still only in its opening stages, but it already has a lot to do. In the interest of avoiding spoilers, I shall only say that many things happen, and you can choose your level of involvement. Do you stay aloof and neutral, fully back your allies, or maybe just go on your way, seeking out another distant star for different opportunities? 

The galaxy is full of secrets, potential, allies and enemies. Make no mistake, your first Captain will die. And likely your second and third as well. The difficulty scale in this game is not a joke. Even as an experienced player, I still lose Captains to careless mistakes, falling behind the difficulty curve, or simple bad luck. However, if you prefer a less harrowing experience, the lower difficulty options will make for a more forgiving world, perfect to learn in until you feel that you can move up to the next rung on the ladder. 

Finally, the devs, the Trese Brothers, are always looking to improve their games, and have an excellent track record of doing so. In the closed Alpha alone there have been over 60 updates, and if the original Star Traders RPG is anything to go by, there will likely be hundreds more in the pipeline. The devs are almost always on their forum or in their Discord server, and they are always happy to take suggestions, requests for new features, and answer questions. 

Now Captain, the Crew are at their stations, the Engines are warming up, and the galaxy awaits you. May the stars welcome you with all their light.

36518822.review:
I've been an active  member of the Alpha community for Star Traders: Frontiers since it went live, and I have to say that it's been the most wonderful experience ever spent playing and assisting in the creation/debugging of one of the most satisfying and challenging sandbox universes crafted.

For your $15 you are buying access to one of the most positive and friendly communities, as well as a deep and engaging sandbox game that allows you to gear your ship toward whatever style of play you find most exciting, whether it be trading, spying, fighting, or just exploring. 

You get:

-Map Generation that is seeded carefully so as to make every quadrant feel unique and engaging, instead of just giving you extra "random" content. 

-A Job System that allows for both extreme focus, and broad protection. The choice on how each of your crew members should select their feats is up to you. Re-assigning their perks is just a click of a button away.

-Ship combat that is both tactical and terrifying, where your prowess as a captain is your best defense, but every torpedo fired may be the last one that you need, or the last one that your opponent does.

-All your actions have consequences. Kill off the opposition to your favorite contacts, or balance their powers and profit off of the blood feud. Your actions will change the world around you, and the impact will only deepen as development continues.

The developers are active every day, and in contact almost 24/7 trying to craft the best gaming experience they can. It is the kind of game they would (and do) play, and they are very proud of that fact. Once you join this community, you will be, too.

36518709.review:
This is a difficult game to properly describe, but it's a Space Trade Exploration Adventure RPG with Global Events triggering things throughout the galaxy.  That being said, it can also be played as a sandbox game.

Choose your primary Career, your Faction affiliation, select your initial skill and attributes, hire and train your crew, purchase and upgrade your ship, promote your best crew to Officers, and launch yourself into the void of space.  Whether you play as a merchant, pirate, spy, explorer, military commander (or several other careers), you'll be challenged by faction wars, trade bans, offers of missions to faraway sectors with great risk/reward, hostile ship attacks, and the ever-present risk of Xeno attacks in space or wilderness zones.

As you trade between economic zones on various planets, accept missions for payments, hold pirates ransom, spy on enemy planets, sell intel to your contacts, patrol friendly territory, blockade your enemies and blow hostile ships to smithereens, you and your crew will be gaining valuable experience and learning new jobs and talents. Upgrade your ship, crew weapons, armor and enhancements, deploy specialized gear to maximize your career goals. The contacts you meet will offer missions to enhance your reputation with factions (or turn you into a war criminal with other factions).  Many of the missions lead to story arcs in which you can help shape major events and shake up the galaxy.

The decisions are yours Captain.  You are a Star Trader.

The Trese Brothers have polished the game to a very usable state, hence the release to Early Access.  They are known for constantly updating their games to improve balance, add new features (often from players just like you and I), fix bugs, and provide new content.  See Templar Battleforce and Heroes of Steel for examples of their commitment.

In short, definitely recommend this game.

If you would like to get a basic  introduction of the game mechanics take a look at the 
Wiki pages for Star Traders Frontiers.   As the game, and rules expand.  The Wiki pages are automatically updated.The Wiki pages just scratch the surface, you really need to experience the depth for yourself in realtime play. 

I can write four or five pages.  But that wouldn't be a review, and who would have the patience to read it.  When looking for a new game, my eyes glaze over after about a page.  That length belongs in a Steam guide I’ll be putting together later.  

There is an Advanced mode button.  This lets you create your Captain, Officers, and crew
to your exact finely detailed specifications. Quick start is like looking at your watch to see what time it is.  Advanced is like building your own watch.  Advanced will offer you all 9 current Captain types to start with instead of 4.  Each Captain and officer will develop up to 3 jobs as you play.

This game is not frozen in carbonite.  Trese Brothers will continue to add content and fix bugs long after purchase. As normal, Steam will update with the new versions as they are released.

Quick Start:
After installing if you want to jump right in without allot of setup, there are 4 pre-made Captain templates for you to choose from. You can start playing in two or three minutes.
   
Select a Template and Click the Launch button.
Choose game difficulty.
Choose a Map: You can use the default map or create your own.
Choose a Faction:  Which house or Syndicate do you want to join at the beginning.
Customize, Choose from male or  female Captains.  How do you want your Captain to dress
What does the face look like and more.
Click the Launch button

Simple right?  You just started a very long fun journey.  How, when, and the people you interact with in this game determines your fate.  Each of them has enemies and friends, if you perform a service for one contact are you helping or hurting someone else in a distant quadrant?  When you meet them they won’t forget what you did.  If you return from a mission is your contact still alive?

Crew & Officers:  Each of them have their own distinct personalities, and traits.  You can decide to promote them, fire them, or just take a calculated risk.  They can quit or even mutiny.  What makes a crew member tick affects the rest of the crew, and ship performance.  Like everybody else none of them are completely good or bad.  You will not automatically understand who they are, hidden traits will be revealed during game play. 

Hot Keys, are increasingly rare in laptop/desktop games.  Saves allot of clicks.  Hover over an icon to reveal the keyboard shortcut.  The Escape key is your best friend to exit cutscenes you have seen a dozen times before, and backing out of other screens quickly.

I’ve done my best to keep the review brief.  If you want to know more, Steam guides are being prepared.  Google “Trese Brothers” to see hundreds of helpful Forum  threads, and as mentioned above take a look at the Wiki pages.   I have played for almost a year. 

 Buy it, try, it and be immersed.  Leave your everyday life behind for a few hours downtime every day.

36517275.review:
Le nouveau jeu des frères Trese est enfin là. On peut s'attendre à un suivi exemplaire, avec des dizaines de mises à jour dans les mois et même années à venir (leur excellent Templar Battleforce par exemple a reçu plus de 70 mises à jour sur 3 ans, gratuites, et au delà des attentes légitimes d'un accès anticipé).

Ayant eu l'opportunité de jouer pendant l'alpha, je sais déjà que Star Traders : Frontiers est un jeu d'une très grande richesse, très rejouable grâce à la vingtaine de métiers différents, aux histoires à tiroirs, et à l'univers qui évolue en parallèle des actions du joueur.

C'est un jeu à l'échelle humaine : on y incarne un pilote et son équipage, à bord d'un vaisseau. L'objectif n'est pas de conquérir la galaxie, les différentes factions en lice s'en sont déjà chargé. Il va plutôt falloir exploiter les filons politiques et économiques, influencer les décisions des grands de l'univers, saboter ou soutenir sa faction, afin de se faire une place dans les étoiles, faire fructifier sa situation, satisfaire son équipage, et mériter son statut de Star Trader.

39494711.review:
Star Traders: Frontiers doesn't look like much, it really doesn't. 

And yet, just like another famous sc-fi construct, once you get inside, there's alot here.

In brief it's a 2d open-world space rpg that unlike may others doesn't try and lock into you to just trading to get anywhere in decent time.
Yeah, I'm looking at  you Elite Dangerous.

So here have both turn-based starship combat in the vain of ancient DOS-era rpg Buck Roger's Countdown to Doomsday (look it up. Then dos-box and play it. Really!) AND crew postion based turn-combat lifted straight out of that brilliant gothic Go-Mad-And-Die 'Em up Darkest Dungeon. 
Wrap it all an open world world map of dynamic factions who ally, war, and screw each other over in a sci-fi setting that looks heavily inspired by Frank Herbert's Dune, Warhammer 40k and the lightspeed Age of Sail stylings of long-dead 90's tabletop RPG Fading Suns and you have Star Traders: Frontiers.

Ok, so far, so cliched sci-fi meanderings, right? Well the lore genuinely feels more like fond tribute than generic rip-off for one but still why is this game good?

It's about the things Star Traders strides forwards with where it's peers and predecesors stumbled.

The game world not only feels genuinely dynamic in a Total War Campaign Map kinda way, but Star Traders really maske you feel like you can influence things: the tasks you choose really feed into your faction's performance or undercut that of an opposing one. Random events that happen in a system really affect the kinds of encounter you will have: a sector might experience a trade boom with more merchant ships flooding the space lanes with laden cargo holds. A rise in local tensions will have aggressive military ships running stop searches on you cargo holds. There's a feeling of ebb and flow.

It gives you ley-way rather than forcing you into certain playstyle, be it letting you build your character,crew and ship for smuggling (which has quite and in depth mechanic), boarding and bounty capturing, long-haul trading, resource gathering or straight up carnage. Piracy is viable (and very profitable) and combat isn't punishing.

Your crew matters! They're full customisable, learn and level up skills that will form that will be crucial to your success.  In many ways how you manage them will tailor your play style: you can recruit them to specialise your ships role or train them to fill in the gaps in your captain's resume, eg giving a combat spec'd character the ability to engage in smuggling, espionage and exploration.
These motley men and women will fight for you, die for you, desert you, even betray you if your not careful and develop their own traits and quirks as time goes on. 

Did I mention this all just Early Access? There are already a few NPC's with branching quest lines and at least one big event that spawned a new faction. And the dev's (a two-man team I believe) are dropping content regulary. In the past 3 days alone there have been daily updates adding content.

A word of warning though, and this is important - Star Traders: Frontiers is A ROGUELIKE- there is one save file that updates automatically. NO MANUAL SAVES - a deliberate choice by the dev's so that your choices have consequences. I'm not sure how I feel about this -I see their intent but it doesn't really help trial-and-error or experimental play. Crew and player permadeth is present. Having said that I'm playing on Basic difficulty and the game is very generous with cash, saving throws, and not-to-taxing combat. So just be aware of that.

Anyhow, TLDR - Surprisingly deep 2d spaceship Rogulike with rpg and turn-based tactical combat elements in a dynamic galaxy. Total bargain. Go Play.

J'ai découvert la gamme de jeux Trese Brothers sur mobile, avec STG Elite et Templar Battleforce. Ces jeux sont d'un premier coup d'oeil peu séduisants par leurs graphiques, mais derrière la surface, une profondeur inouïe caractérise les mécanismes de jeux. 

STG Frontiers ne fait pas exception à la règle. Nous n'en sommes qu'en early access et la complexité est incroyable. À chaque détour, je replonge dans le wiki explorer les règles régissant telle et telle action. Bien sûr, vous pouvez jouer en mode léger et passer à côté de tout ça, sans vous en faire avec les règles, mais je vous garantis que ce jeu récompense les capitaines qui n'ont pas froid aux yeux. 

Maintenant, comme tous les jeux des Trese Brothers, je reste sur ma faim quand au visuel. C'est bien loin de nuire au plaisir de jouer, mais même ici, dans STG Frontiers, j'aurais préféré n'avoir aucun visuel de personnage plutôt que des individus au déambulé de marionnette avec des faciès aussi redondants que limités. Clairement, la force des Treses Brothers est leur vision du jeu, qui me rejoint en tout point, de par leur incroyable souci du détail et de la richesse des mécanismes, mais pas dans les graphiques!

Pourquoi acheter ce jeu? 
1. Pour encourager une super équipe de travail passionnée et indépendante
2. Pour jouer à un jeu intelligent qui laisse tout le plaisir au joueur de laisser voguer son imagination au gré de ses choix de capitaine de vaisseau
3. Pour l'extrême rejouabilité du jeu

Bravo au Trese Brothers :)

9/10

39517917.review:
Excluding all reasons that community has already highlighted, my prime reason to give a thumb up is as follows:
Trese Brothers have the best attitude towards community I have ever experienced.

These guys really listen to you, and they take your comments seriously. Moreover, they keep updating their games after purchase without asking for paied DLCs.

That's a massive reason in my book to support their cause; and even justifies a purchase of the game in early access,

Other than this, if you liked "Sid Meier's Pirates" then Star Traders is for you. It's the best port you could have ever imagined. It's pirates in a dynamic world that meets Crusader Kings, or Europa Universalis, or Victoria. It's deep and engaging, your choices matter. In addition the game has lots of mini-games that will keep you engaged like the ground combat that plays like Darkest Dungeon or space combat that reminds me FTL.

That's a big blow for EA, SEGA and all other monsters out there, who make games best on flashy graphics and first impressions. Trese Brothers delivered the best possible outcome using an outdated, low-budget graphic environment.

That's a game for all gamers that like to think. Possibly my best purchase, since CKII.

39591565.review:
I've put some hours in the game now and I definitely recommend it. It's grown so much in the short time I've been playing it. I'm welcomed with a new update from the developer just about every other day. It's amazing to be able to play a game that grows as my experience with it does. It's like constant free DLC!

Early Access besides, the game is really good. Every decision you make has an important impact on the various factions within the games universe. There are many facets of gameplay to explore and experience, such as ship customization and crew load outs. 

The story changes and grows, branching in many directions depending on how to approach the problems you encounter as you progress. 

There's about 6-10 difficulties from 'easy enjoy the story mode' to 'jesus christ what in the *bleep* was I thinking!'. This gives room for plenty of experientation and offer plenty of replay value.

Much is expected to be updated in the many updates, yet today the game remains a solid investment. It doesn't ever "end" as far as I can tell right now so there's a LOT of replay value. Potentially limitless as it stands today.

Finally there are numerous play styles. You can play a Bounty Hunter, attacking pirates and rogues within the various star systems, a Merchant, trading with lands far and wide instead of focusing on combat, you can be a Smuggler, and many others. 

I highly recommend you buy this game! The other reviews are a testament to its current success and it's only expected to get better!

39588700.review:
STF is fun. It's got loads of depth, with lots of different play styles possible. It also gets progressively more challenging as time goes by, which is good.

I particularly like that it's not twitchy at all: you have plenty of time to make each decision.

The Trese Brothers are working hard and extremely responsive, which is gratifying while it's in early access, and gives me confidence that the rough edges will be smoothed before launch. That's not to say that the game is anything like all rough edges; it's a fully functioning fun game already.

You have plenty of choice in how you look, and the NPCs are pleasantly diverse, as are your crew.

I don't regret getting this game at all.

39583891.review:
Fun little game with impressive complexity 

Imagine Sid Meiers Pirates! in space. Throw in some card mechanics, darkest dungeon-style ground combat and you get an idea of what Star Traders:Frontiers is about. 

For a game in Early Access this is a pretty solid game as it is, with the devs (amazing dedicated guys, always active on the forum) adding in more content almost constantly. I'd say this is a good purchase even if you are normally a bit skeptic/careful with EA games. 

You basically play as a captain of a desired profession. Merchant, Smuggler, Spy, Pirate etc.. These choices do affect your playstyle in the game so a bit of pre-planning is worthwhile. There is a storyline (not finished yet) you can follow or you can break from the main story and do your thing. But what's great is that the story progresses no matter if you interact with it or not. This gives the universe life IMO. Not many games do this so it's refreshing to see. 

The game has 6 factions. Contacts (people that offer you jobs) all have their personal agendas. People they support or dislike. So all your actions have political consequences. Gain reputation some place, lose it elsewhere. A great system that keeps the player following his/hers own agenda according to what faction they wanna help. This is pretty complex IMO and makes for some great "roleplaying" opportunities. 

I'm not good at reviews. So for more detailed info check some more indepth ones or come by the forum and ask if you are curious. I give this game a solid recommendation. The devs are fantastic with several games to their name, it's very clear it's a passion project of theirs.  They communicate a lot with the players and are listening to each and every suggestion. So if you wanna help shape the game, maybe come up with some brilliant idea that could make it into the game, now is your chance to do exactly that. 

Regarding stability; So far I haven't had any problems with stability. The game just runs smooth and perfectly.

Just buy this damn game already. It's great.

39580571.review:
[h1] И почему я спал на уроках английского?	[/h1]

Так. Ну где же она!?! Я точно помню, что она была где-то здесь! Куда же могла запропаститься эта маленькая книжечка? Чего встали? Быстренько помогли мне найти мой русско-английский словарь. Мне он просто необходим для следующей игры.

[code][url=store.steampowered.com/curator/11769719/] Если представить что игры в Steam это звезды на небе, то тогда мы исследователи которые собираются открыть их все. Dreams of Genesis[/url][/code]

Дело в том что без хорошего знания инглиша, нет не Джонни, а просто английского языка, в игре делать нечего. Моя практика английским закончилась лет восемь назад, поэтому неудивительно, что мне в некоторых моментах понадобилась помощь словаря, чтобы понять что от меня требуется. Действительно, приготовьтесь, что игра вас встретит обилием текста.

Во время игры меня не переставало покидать ощущение что где то я это все уже видел… В другой интерпретации немного, но определенно видел. Для полноты ощущений не хватало только Доминаторов. Ну вы уже поняли на какую игру я намекаю.

Игра предоставляет игроку огромный, живой мир, на который влияет не только выборы игрока, но и собственные внутренние конфликты которые меняют баланс сил в мире. И вот в этом бурлящем котле нам и предстоит найти свое место. Торговля, пиратство, космический вигилант и прочие. Все пути открыты перед игроком. Игра довольно сложная, так что не думайте что сразу после входа в игру вы на легке сможете подняться из грязи в князи. Игра быстро опустит вас с земли в подземелье, прикует вас к позорному столбу и будет всячески издеваться над вами.

На самом деле это далеко не первая игра в серии Star Traders. До этого в Steam уже выходила игра в этой линейке, да и на мобильных устройствах игра успела побывать и обзавестись группой фанатов. К сожалению, мобильные игры мне далеки, поэтому лично их не проверял.

Графическое исполнение у игры самое что ни на есть простое. Не стоит ждать тут сверх реалистичной картинки космоса, кораблей или продвинутую анимацию. Все выглядит на достаточно примитивном уровне. Не поймите меня неправильно, у графики тут есть свой особый стиль, но она довольно простая. Да и она не важна в ней, главное тут геймплей, а он на высоте.

[h1] Торговец. Бандит. Законник.	[/h1]

Игра зайдет далеко не каждому, если вы не любите просчитывать свои ходы, не обладаете усидчивостью и терпением, то можете смело проходить мимо. Всех же остальных будет приветствовать великолепный живой мир Star Traders.
